Absence or abnormal closure of the posterior portion of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).

value: Chronic rhinitis due to narrow nasal airway

definition: Bilateral absence (atresia) of the posterior nasal aperture (choana).
Hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells.
Increased length of the hairs of the eyebrows.
Reduced or lacking hair growth in the temporal region (i.e., around the temples on the side of the skull).

value: Large clumps of pigment irregularly distributed along hair shaft

definition: Reduced or lacking hair growth in a generalized distribution.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the sacral region.
Anterior cervical hypertrichosis (ACH) or 'hairy throat' refers to the presence of a tuft of terminal hair on the anterior neck, just above the laryngeal prominence.
A confluent, generalized overgrowth of silvery blonde to gray lanugo hair at birth.
Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates affecting the cervical spine.
Increased bone density affecting the bones of the spine (vertebral column).
Bulbous appearance of the anterior vertebral bodies, such that the vertebral bodies have the greatest vertical height anteriorly as well as bulbous anterior superior-inferior contours.
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies.
Increased top to bottom height of vertebral bodies.
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T11 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
Sclerosis (increased density) affecting vertebral end plates.
An excessive concavity of the anterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
Exaggerated concavity of the anterior or posterior surface of the vertebral body, i.e., the upper and lower vertebral endplates are hollowed inward.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the thoracic spine.

value: Hump-shaped mound of bone in central and posterior portions of vertebral endplate

definition: Three ossification sites are present in typical vertebral bodies (C3-L5): a single ossification center in the vertebral body, and one each in the two neural arches. This term applies if there are additional vertebral ossification centers present during the development and maturation of the spine.

value: Absent or minimally ossified vertebral bodies

definition: The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of the vertebra L5 with intact overlying skin.

Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C2 and C3, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development, leading to a short neck with a low hairline at the back of the head, and restricted mobility of the upper spine.
A lack of bone mineralization of the vertebral bodies.
A lack of ossification of the vertebral bodies.

value: Anterior beaking of lower thoracic vertebrae
definition: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the lower thoracic vertebral bodies.
Anterior mislocalization of the dens of the axis.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of S1 with intact overlying skin.
A discontinuity of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends.
Increased size of the vertebral pedicle.
A progressive form of decreased height of the intervertebral disk.
Presence of abnormal convexity of the upper and lower end plates of the vertebrae, i.e., an exaggerated bulging out of the upper and lower vertebral end plates.
Reduced size of cervical vertebrae.
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of thoracic vertebral bodies.

value: Decreased cervical spine flexion due to contractures of posterior cervical muscles

definition: An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of cervical vertebrae during development.
Over curvature of the lower thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
Fusion of the C5 and C6 cervical vertebrae.
An elevation of alpha-feto protein measured in the amniotic fluid.
Underdevelopment of the nasal bone.
Underdevelopment of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead).
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the midline region of the face.
A reduced degree of voluntary and involuntary facial movements involved in responded to others or expressing emotions.
Narrow, paramedian longitudinal depressions in the plantar skin of the forefoot.
Outward turning of the heel, resulting in clubfoot with the person walking on the inner part of the foot.
Underdevelopment of the Third metatarsal bone leading to a short (hypoplastic) third metatarsal bone.
Short fourth metatarsal bone.
An abnormal thickening of the Achilles tendon.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two and three.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes four and five.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the calcaneus.
Decrease in mass and density of the metatarsal bones.
Short (hypoplastic) fifth metatarsal bone.
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal orientation of the kidney.
Acute renal failure with resolution of manifestations.
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal axial orientation of the kidney.
An increase in amplitude of waves returned in ultrasonography of the kidney, which is generally displayed as increased brightness of the signal.
Prominent glomerular basement membrane (GBM), reflecting an increase in thickness (subjective estimate) of the basal lamina of the glomerulus of the kidney.
The presence of calcium-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
A defect in the ability to concentrate the urine.
Acute inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
A reduction in the ability of the kidneys to remove uric acid from the serum.
Cysts of microscopic size confined to the cortex of the kidney.

A developmental anomaly in which the kidneys are fused and localized on the same side of the midline. This anomaly is thought to result from disruption of the normal embryologic migration of the kidneys.

Obliteration of the glomerular capillary lumen by increased collagenous matrix, with or without hyalinosis or foam cells. Sclerosis involves 100% of the glomerular tuft. Relative to other patent glomeruli in the sample, glomerular size is preserved, or increased/decreased by no more than 50%.
An abnormality of the renal collecting system.
Chronic inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
Electron dense deposits at the glomerular basement membrane,

A type of atrial arrhythmia characterized by atrial rates of between 240 and 400 beats per minute and some degree of atrioventricular node conduction block. Typically, the ventricular rate is half the atrial rate. In the EKG; atrial flutter waves are observed as sawtooth-like atrial activity. Pathophysiologically, atrial flutter is a form of atrial reentry in which there is a premature electrical impulse creates a self-propagating circuit.
Episodes of ventricular tachycardia that have a sudden onset and ending.
A form of atrioventricular (AV) dissociation (i.e., the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers) with congenital onset.
AF that cannot be successfully terminated by cardioversion, and longstanding (more than 1 year) AF, where cardioversion is not indicated or has not been attempted, is termed permanent.
Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is an abnormally increased heart rate (over 100 beats per minute at rest) with origin above the level of the ventricles.
A tachycardia originating in the ventricles characterized by rapid heart rate (over 100 beats per minute) and broad QRS complexes (over 120 ms).
Episodes of atrial fibrillation that typically last for several hours up to one day and terminate spontaneously.
Polymorphic ventricular arrhythmias of varying morphologythat do not exist under resting conditions but appear only upon physical exercise or catecholamine administration.

value: obsolete Nodular calcific aortic valve disease

definition: Underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart right ventricle, often due to a reduced number of cells.
An episodic form of supraventricular tachycardia with abrupt onset and termination.

Myxomatous mitral valve is defined as the presence of excess leaflet tissue and leaflet thickening greater than 5 mm, resulting in a prolapse greater than 2 mm into the left atrium on parasternal long axis view.
Decreased number of head hairs per unit area on the anterior region of the scalp.
Fragile, easily breakable scalp hair.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the elbow region.
Presence of multiple polyps in the duodenum.

The presence of multiple juvenile polyps in the stomach and intestine. The term juvenile polyps refer to a special histopathology and not the age of onset as the polyp might be diagnosed at all ages. The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands. Juvenile polyps are a specific type of hamartomatous polyps.
An anatomical anomaly that results from an abnormal rotation of the gut as it returns to the abdominal cavity during embryogenesis.
Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice.
Fluid retention and edema in the intestine caused by a compromised lymphatic system.
An inability to digest lactose.
Underdevelopment of the small intestine.
Defect in the epithelium of the esophagus, essentially an open sore in the lining of the esophagus.
The presence of a fistula between the perineum and the rectum.
A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel.
Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas located in the stomach.
The presence of multiple areas of atresia affecting the small intestine.

value: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract
definition: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract.
A form of hemolytic anemia that occurs in repeated episodes.
A form of hemolytic anemia with congenital onset.
A form of leukemia characterized by overproduction of an early myeloid cell.
Low platelet count associated with maternal platelet-specific alloantibodies.
A type of hypoplastic anemia with congenital onset.
A type of ALL characterized by elevated levels of B-cell lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and the blood.

Sudden onset of thrombocytopenia (reduced platelet count) within 5-10 days of the transfusion of blood products. The clinical presentation is post-transfusion purpura (PTP), wigth severe thrmbocytopenia, epistaxis, and hemorrhages.
A kind of hemolytic anemia that is induced by the ingestion of fava beans.
A form of hemolytic anemia that is triggered by ingestion of certain drugs.
A type of hypoplastic anemia in which the erythrocytes have a normal cell volume (the mean corpuscular volume is within normal limits).
An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.
An excessive division of the lobes of the nucleus of a neutrophil.
A type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence in the blood of erythrocytes of varying sizes and abnormal shapes.
An abnormal increase in the binding affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

A type of megaloblastic anemia that does not improve upon administration of folate. Since vitamin B12 acts by promoting recycling of folate, administration of vitamin B12 also does not improve this type of anemia.

A type of myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by less than 5% myeloblasts in the bone marrow, but with 15% or greater red cell precursors in the marrow being abnormal iron-stuffed cells called ringed sideroblasts.
Repeated episodes of obstruction of blood flow due to an embolus, i.e., blood clot that has traveled from its point of origin within the blood stream.
The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped and reduced in size.
A type of acute myeloid leukemia in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate.
A form of severe hemolytic anemia characterized by erythrocyte morphology reminiscent of that seen in patients after a thermal burn.
A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.

Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade.
A type of hemolytic anemia in which the Coombs test is positive.
The accumulation of transformed primitive hematopoietic blast cells, which lose their ability of normal differentiation and proliferation.
Bleeding that persists longer than the normal time following a surgical procedure.

A subset of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that results from a reciprocal translocation between the ABL-1 oncogene and a breakpoint cluster region (BCR), resulting in a fusion gene, BCR-ABL, that encodes an oncogenic protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity.
Repeated episodes of the formation of a blot clot in a deep vein.
A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of folate.
Decreased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes.
Reduced platelet count that occurs sporadically, i.e., it comes and goes.
An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein S. Protein S is a cofactor of protein C.
A type of anemia characterized by an normal concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.
A type of anemia characterized by abnormally large erythrocytes with abnormally high amounts of haemoglobin.
Thrombocytopenia related to lack of or severe reduction in the count of megakaryocytes.
A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of thiamine.
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is not responsive to treatment.
Abnormal platelet response to ADP as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ADP.
An chronic form of hemolytic anemia.
The presence of a fistula between the bowel and the perineum.
An abdominal hernia that occurs at a site of weakness in the abdominal wall resulting from an incompletely-healed surgical wound.
Pneumothorax occurring neonatally without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.
Lack of strength of the intercostal muscles, i.e., of the muscle groups running along the ribs that create and move the chest wall.
Episodic hyperventilation.
Increased susceptibility to respiratory infections in early life, as manifested by recurrent episodes of respiratory infections.
A state of respiratory distress that requires a life saving intervention in the form of gaining airway access and instituting positive pressure ventilation.

value: Intermittent episodes of respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness

definition: An abnormally elevated blood pressure in the circulation of the pulmonary artery.
Increased susceptibility to infections due to aspiration, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infections due to aspiration.
A form of lactic acidemia that occurs in relation to stress or infection.
A continuous form of lactic acidemia.
A severe form of lactic acidemia.
A form of lactic acidemia that occurs following exercise or exertion.
A form of lactic acidemia with congenital onset.

The term Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) was initially used for patients diagnosed with fasting hyperglycemia that could be treated without insulin for more than two years, where the initial diagnosis was made at a young age (under 25 years). Thus, MODY combines characteristics of type 1 diabetes (young age at diagnosis) and type 2 diabetes (less insulin dependence than type 1 diabetes). The term MODY is now most often used to refer to a group of monogenic diseases with these characteristics. Here, the term is used to describe hyperglycemia diagnosed at a young age with no or minor insulin dependency, no evidence of insulin resistence, and lack of evidence of autoimmune destruction of the beta cells.
A reduced concentration of vitamin A.
Repeated transient episodes of metabolic acidosis, that is, of the buildup of acid or depletion of base due to accumulation of metabolic acids.
An intermittent (discontinuous) form of lactic acidemia.
Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood occurring during the infantile period.
An impairment of galactose metabolism.
A form of metabolic acidosis with increased serum chloride levels.
An abnormality of magnesium ion homeostasis.
An increased concentration of L-phenylalanine in the blood.
An abnormal resistance to glucose, i.e., a reduction in the ability to maintain glucose levels in the blood stream within normal limits following oral administration of glucose.
A chronic form of lactic acidemia.

value: Orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction

definition: An abnormal widening of the diameter of the pulmonary artery.
Arteriosclerosis (increased thickness, increased stiffness, loss of elasticity) of the small arteries of the brain.

A separation of the layers within the wall of the ascending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.
Abnormal calcification of the vasculature.
A congenital anomaly with a narrowing or complete absence of the opening between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
An aneurysm (severe localized balloon-like outward bulging) in the pulmonary artery.
Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts, affecting arteries distributed throughout the body.
Increased pressure in the pre-hepatic portal vein.

Aortic dilatation refers to a dimension that is greater than the 95th percentile for the normal person age, sex and body size. In contrast, an aneurysm is defined as a localized dilation of the aorta that is more than 150 percent of predicted (ratio of observed to expected diameter 1.5 or more). Aneurysm should be distinguished from ectasia, which represents a diffuse dilation of the aorta less than 50 percent of normal aorta diameter.

Atherosclerosis which occurs in a person with certain risk factors (e.g., SLE, diabetes, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, family history of early heart disease) at an earlier age than would occur in another person without those risk factors.
The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the extracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall.
An abnormal connection between an artery and vein.
Abnormal twisting of arteries or veins.

Narrowing of peripheral arteries with reduction of blood flow to the limbs. This feature may be quantified as an ankle-brachial index of less than 0.9, and may be manifested clinically as claudication.
A rare vascular anomaly with a direct communication between pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary bed.

value: obsolete Dilatation of the descending aorta

definition: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries affecting most or all arteries.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the descending thoracic aorta.
A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery.
An anomalous origin of the left pulmonary artery, such that it arises from the posterior aspect of the right pulmonary artery and passes between the trachea and esophagus to reach the left hilum.
An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the thoracic aorta.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the aorta.
Increase in mass of the tunica media of the arteries in the pulmonary circulation.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of large (conduit) arteries.
Recurrent bleeding into the parenchyma of the brain.
Stenosis of a peripheral branch of the pulmonary artery.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the tubular part of the ascending aorta.
Underdevelopment of the pulmonary artery.
An abnormal increase in the average blood pressure in an individual during a single cardiac cycle.
Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the abdominal aorta.

value: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femurs
definition: Flaring of distal femur.
Missing radius bone on both sides associated with congenital failure of development.
Abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Reduction in density of metaphyseal bony tissue.
Shortening of the middle parts of the leg in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of the arm (i.e. the humerus).

value: Slender long bones with narrow diaphyses
definition: Reduced diameter of a long bone with a more pronounced reduction of the diameter of the diaphysis of the long bones.

value: Multicentric ossification of proximal humeral epiphyses

definition: Patellar dislocation occurring repeated times.

value: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the capital femoral epiphysis
definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
An abnormally flat form of the proximal epiphysis of the radius.

value: Femoral bowing present at birth, straightening with time
definition: Congenital onset bending or abnormal curvature of the femur that normalizes with age.
The humerus is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.

value: Osteomyelitis leading to amputation due to slow healing fractures

definition: Shortening of the middle parts of the arm in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Abnormally developed (dysplastic) distal epiphysis of the radius.
Underdevelopment of the distal portion of the humerus.
Underdevelopment of the distal portion of the ulna.

value: Shortening of all phalanges of the toes
definition: Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of all phalanges of the foot.
Underdevelopment of the ulna on only one side.
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the proximal portions of the radius and the ulna.
Multiple exostoses originating in long bones.
Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth capital femoral epiphysis.
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis at the proximal end of the humerus (at the shoulder).
An elevation in bone density of the cortex of one or more diaphyses. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterolateral direction.
Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis.

value: Cone-shaped epiphyses fused within their metaphyses

definition: Overgrowth of the proximal part of the fibula.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an proximal direction.
The ability of the wrist joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterior direction.
A limited ability of the knee joint to perform extension and flexion.
An abnormality of the pattern of trabecula (small interconnecting rods of bone) in a metaphyseal region of bone.
A lateral bending or abnormal curvature of the femur.
The presence of streaks (bands) of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Absence of the proximal radial epiphysis.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the femur.

value: Premature birth following premature rupture of fetal membranes

definition: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the higher frequencies of sound (3,000 to 6,000 Hz).
Deterioration or loss of the tissues of the cochlea.
Ossification affecting the external ear cartilage.
Underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
Any abnormality of the vertebral end plates, which are the top and bottom portions of the vertebral bodies that interface with the vertebral discs.
An abnormality of the sacral bone.
An abnormality of the intervertebral disk.
An abnormality of the Achilles tendon.

An atrial arrhythmia characterized by disorganized atrial activity without discrete P waves on the surface EKG, but instead by an undulating baseline or more sharply circumscribed atrial deflections of varying amplitude an frequency ranging from 350 to 600 per minute.

value: obsolete Dilatation of the ascending aorta

definition: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the abdominal aorta.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch.

value: obsolete Abnormalities of the peripheral arteries

definition: A type of arrhythmia that originates above the ventricles, whereby the electrical impulse propagates down the normal His Purkinje system similar to normal sinus rhythm.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries.
Abnormal increase in diastolic blood pressure.
Any structural abnormality of a cardiac atrium.
An excessive concavity of the posterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
Compression of the heart caused by rigid, thickened, or fused pericardial membranes.
Enlargement of the chamber of the right ventricle.
Refers to the specific combination of defects with a severely dysplastic pulmonary valve and massively dilated branch pulmonary arteries.
An abnormality of the T wave on the electrocardiogram, which mainly represents the repolarization of the ventricles.
Mitral annular calcification (MAC) results from progressive calcium deposition along and beneath the mitral valve annulus.

value: Anomalous origin of right pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
definition: The right pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery.
The dividing wall between left and right sides of the heart, thickens and bulges into the left ventricle.
Abnormal narrowing of the coronary artery.
Abnormal calcification of a cardiac valve.
Any defect in the valve connecting the heart and the pulmonary artery.
An impairment of the electrical continuity between the atria and ventricles.
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized proximal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the preductal region of aortic arch.
A type of cardiomyopathy characterized pathologically by hamartomatous lesions of cardiac Purkinje cells.

A ventircular escape rhythm occurs whenever higher-lever pacemakers in AV junction or sinus node fail to control ventricular activation. Escape rate is usually 20-40 bpm, often associated with broad QRS complexes (at least 120 ms).
Underdeveloped, small left heart atrium
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an symmetrical and concentric pattern of hypertrophy.

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return refers to a congenital malformation in which all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, but instead drain abnormally to the right atrium.

Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.
A congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Reduced time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex). In adults, normal values are 120 to 200 ms long.
An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the right atrium.

value: Complete heart block with broad QRS complexes
definition: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at a relatively low part of the conduction system (below the atrioventricular node), which produces a wide QRS complex.
Conduction block in the posterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.
Subvalvular stenosis is caused by a diaphragm-like membrane. The stenosis is clinically manifested like any other form of aortic stenosis but is often associated with some aortic insufficiency.
A congenital malformation of the aortic valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.

value: Complete heart block with narrow QRS complexes
definition: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at the atrioventricular node, which produces a narrow QRS complex.
Failure of the tricuspid valve to close sufficiently upon contraction of the right ventricle, causing blood to regurgitate (flow backward) into the right atrium.
Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries before age of 45.
The presence of a bicuspid pulmonary valve.
An abnormal dilatation of lymph vessels in the pericardium.

A longer than normal interval (corrected for heart rate) between the Q and T waves in the heart's cycle. Prolonged QTc can cause premature action potentials during late phase depolarizations thereby leading to ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillations.

A reduced ejection fraction and an enlarged left ventricle chamber, the latter by an increased resistance to filling with increased filling pressures. Systolic dysfunction is clinically associated with left ventricular failure in the presence of marked cardiomegaly.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.
Interphalangeal joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in the interphalangeal joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.

value: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
definition: Absence of the abdominal musculature.
A recurrent infection of the GI tract with helicobacter pylori, a gram-negative, microaerophilic bacterium usually found in the stomach.
The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis.
Hypertrophy of the stomach.
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
The presence of cyst of the intrahepatic bile duct.
Underdevelopment of the colon.

Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas.
Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.
Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection.
An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum.
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon.
Obstruction affecting the biliary tree.
A chronic form of gastritis.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas.
The presence of a hypoplastic gallbladder.
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification.
The presence of degenerative changes of the liver.
A congenital defect characterized by the lack of ganglion cells in the entire intestine, i.e., the aganglionic segment comprises the entire large and small bowel.
Atresia in the extrahepatic bile duct.
Failure to form of portions of the abdominal musculature.
Developmental hypoplasia of the intestine.
A type of gastritis characterized by excessive proliferation of the gastric mucosa and diffuse thickening of the gastric mucosal folds.

value: Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
definition: Underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.
Atresia in the intrahepatic bile duct.
Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor.

value: Unilateral absence of pectoralis major muscle
definition: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor on only one side of the chest.

value: Abnormal facility in opposing the shoulders

definition: Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
An abnormality of the gallbladder.
An abnormality of the jejunum, i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.

value: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility

definition: A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.

Exaggerated bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion, or commissure).
Lack of the cartilage of the nasal septum.
Posterior positioning of the nasal root in relation to the overall facial profile for age.
Abnormality of the nostril.

value: Intimal thickening in the coronary arteries

definition: A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.

Pseudocoarctation is a congenital anomaly of kinking, or buckling, of the aorta without a pressure gradient across the lesion. It is characterized by elongation and kinking of the aorta at the level of the ligamentum arteriosum.
Peripheral arterial stenosis with onset before the age of 50 years.

value: obsolete Atrioventricular canal defect with right ventricle aorta and pulmonary atresia

definition: A rare congenital vascular anomaly that results when the left superior cardinal vein caudal to the innominate vein fails to regress.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the arch of aorta.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
The presence of a capillary hemangioma, which are hemangiomas with small endothelial spaces.
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta.
A developmental defect characterized by the lack of formation of the pulmonary blood vessels.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries in the pulmonary circulation.

An arterial lesion that is characterized by either intimal fibroplasia, with neointimal lesions of cells and matrix deposition, or medial fibroplasia, in which there is loss of smooth muscle cells and increased deposition of collagen and proteoglycans in the medial layer.

value: Anomalous branches of internal carotid artery

definition: Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) more than 3 wood units, as defined by the current definition of pulmonary hypertension. 95% of individuals have a PVR of less than 2.4 wood units.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.

A type of craniofacial dysostosis associated with abnormalities of the external ears, mirognathia, macrostomia, coloboma of the lower eyelid, and cleft palate. This is a bundled term that is left in the HPO now for convenience with legacy annotations but should not be used for new annotations.
Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.

value: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
definition: A pattern of hair growth in which there is hair extending from the temples to the lateral eyebrows.
Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
Recurrent partial dislocations of the mandible.
Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
An abnormality of the complement system.
Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
Underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
Any structural abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches.
An abnormality of the structure of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.
Hypoplasia of the epiglottis.
A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms.
Increased susceptibility to herpesvirus, as manifested by recurrent episodes of herpesvirus.
Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
A reduced level of the complement component Factor I in circulation.

Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity.
Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination.
Increased susceptibility to chicken pox, as manifested by recurrent episodes of chicken pox.
A general term referring to a defect in immunity resulting from impaired antibody production.
A severe form of B lymphocytopenia in which the count of B cells is very low or absent.
Increased susceptibility to streptococcus pneumoniae infections as manifested by a history of recurrent infections by streptococcus pneumoniae.
An abnormality of the humoral immune system, which comprises antibodies produced by B cells as well as the complement system.
A reduced level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
An abnormality of the physiological functioning of B cells.
An immunodeficiency characterized by defective cell-mediated immunity or humoral immunity.
Increased susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae infections as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by Haemophilus influenzae.
Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
A reduced ability of a B cell to become activated, i.e., the change in morphology and behavior of
Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.

A group of phenotypically heterogeneous genetic disorders characterized by profound deficiencies of T- and B-cell function, which predispose the patients to both infectious and noninfectious complications.

value: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
definition: An abnormal reduction in the components of the alternative complement pathway, such as the C3 protein or its cleavage products.

Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.
Increased susceptibility to coronavirus 229e, as manifested by recurrent episodes of coronavirus 229e.
An abnormal reduction of the cell motility of neutrophils.
An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections.
An abnormally low count of T cells.
An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells.
Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections of the skin, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infectious dermatitis.

value: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
definition: A decreased proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count.

value: obsolete Markedly reduced T cell function

definition: Persistent overgrowth of Candida albicans in the gastrointestinal tract.

An abnormally increased level of circulationg alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant.

value: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive T cells
definition: A decreased proportion of circulating CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells relative to total number of T cells.
A reduced level of the complement component factor B in circulation.
Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
Increased susceptibility to infection by gram-negative bacteria, as manifested by a medical history of repeated or frequent infections by these agents.
A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation.
Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells
An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
Absence of specific immunoglobulins directed against a specific antigen or microorganism.
An increased susceptibility to infections involving both the paranasal sinuses and the lungs, as manifested by a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
Increased susceptibility to systemic pyogenic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of systemic pyogenic infections.
Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).

At birth, newborns are endowed with maternal antibodies. IgG production normally begins at the age of two months. A delay in recovery from this physiological hypogammaglobulinemia between the 3rd and the 6th month of life, and of recovery period between 18 and 36 months defines transient newborn hypogammaglobulinemia.
Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.

value: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
definition: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood.
Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex.
An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration.
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Abnormal increased size of the posterior cranial fossa.

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).
Aplasia or hypoplasia of the paranasal sinuses.
Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus.

Normally, the posterior and lateral fontanelles are obliterated by about six months after birth, the anterior fontanelle closes by about the middle of the second year. This term refers to the situation in which the fontanelles close at an inappropriately early time point.
The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri.
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
Underdevelopment of the frontal bone.
Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
Bony fusion of malleus, incus, and stapes.
Abnormal reduction in ossification of the calvaria (roof of the skull consisting of the frontal bone, parietal bones, temporal bones, and occipital bone).
The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Progressively increasing bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin E (IgE) in blood.

value: Abnormality of the alternative complement pathway
definition: A deviation in any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
An abnormality of the epiglottis.
Head circumference which falls below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender because of insufficient head growth after birth.
A fontanelle that is small for age.
Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead.
The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly).

value: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
definition: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root.

value: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles

definition: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate.

Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues.
Presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin M protein in the serum.
A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation.
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.
A reduction in the ability of neutrophils to kill the gram-positive bacteria, staphylococcus, which is commonly known as staph.
Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow.
A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas.
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes.

A chronic form of disseminated intravascular coagulation in which a persistent weak or intermittent activating stimulus is present and destruction and production of coagulation factors and platelets are balanced.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels.
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment.

A malignant lymphocytic neoplasm of B-cell or T-cell lineage involving primarily the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. This category includes precursor or acute lymphoblastic leukemias and chronic leukemias.
Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade.
A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat.

A type of actue leukemia with features characteristic of both the myeloid and lymphoid lineages. These leukemias are for this reason are designated mixed-lineage, hybrid or biphenotypic acute leukemias.

A unique clonal neoplastic disorder that is linked to trisomy 21, is restricted to neonatal period, and spontaneously regresses. It often has characteristics of megakaryocytic lineage and is associated with GATA1 mutations in myeloblasts.
A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion.
Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval.

A form of lymphoid leukemia or lymphoma in which too many T-cell lymphoblasts are found in the blood, bone marrow, and tissues. Leukemia or lymphoma classification depends on which feature is more prominent.
A form of poikilocytosis in which the abnormally shaped erythrocytes have notches that results in projections that look like horns.
Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot.

An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va.
Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential.
A reduced count of megakaryocytes.

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.

The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone of the skull in infants and children and generally undergoes fusion by the age of six. A persistent frontal suture is referred to as a "metopic suture".
An abnormality of the zygomatic arch, also known as the cheek bone.

A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.

Normal hemoglobin synthesis is characterized by production of equal amounts of alpha and beta globins. This term refers to a deviation from this pattern and is the main characteristic of the various forms of thalassemia.

value: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
definition: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow.
The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney.
A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia.

A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption without bicarbonate loss.

A thrombotic microangiopathy with presence of non-immune, intravascular hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and acute kidney injury. A vicious cycle of complement activation, endothelial cell damage, platelet activation, and thrombosis is the hallmark of the disease.

A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
Any impairment of reabsorption of chloride by the kidney in order to not lose too much chloride in the urine.
A duplication of the renal pelvis.
DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney.
A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in which only certain areas of the palms and soles are affected.
The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes.

value: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches

definition: Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.

value: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution
definition: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution.
The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child.

value: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
definition: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders.
The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.
Absence or underdevelopment of the femur.

An abnormally increased rate of skeletal maturation. Accelerated skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance.
The ability of the interphalangeal joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately.
Absent ossification of the calvaria (vault of the skull).
Osteoporosis affecting predominantly the vertebrae.
Bony fusion of the posterior part of the L5 vertebral body with the sacrum.
This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes.

value: Decreased anterioposterior diameter of lumbar vertebral bodies

definition: The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the third toe.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition of the intervertebral disk.
Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints.
Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
Moderate osteoporosis.
Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.
Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella.
Extreme thickening of the cortex of long bones.
Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.
Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain.
An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
A tongue-like protusion from the anterior aspect of lumbar vertebral bodies.

An inherited primary limb malformation disorder characterized by congenital contractures of two or more different body areas and without primary neurologic and/or muscle disease that affects limb function.
Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.

value: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole

definition: Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles.

value: Partial fusion of proximal row of carpal bones

definition: Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal.

value: Increased bone density with cystic changes

definition: A bilateral form of triphalangeal thumb.
Abnormal reduction in length of all metacarpal bones.
The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
A form of triphalangeal thumb that cannot be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.
An abnormal irregularity of cortical bone.

value: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance
definition: An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal related to a reduction in the interpedicular distance (i.e., the distance measured between the pedicles on frontal [coronal] imaging).
Underdevelopment (reduced size) of the tibia.
Partial dislocation of the head of the radius in the posterior direction.

value: Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis
definition: Avascular necrosis of the proximal epiphysis of the femur occurring in growing children and caused by an interruption of the blood supply to the head of the femur close to the hip joint. The necrosis is characteristically associated with flattening of the femoral head, for which reason the term coxa plana has been used to refer to this feature in the medical literature.

value: obsolete Generalized osteoporosis with pathologic fractures
Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull
definition: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull).

value: Contractures of the joints of the lower limbs

definition: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses during the neonatal period.
Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.
An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the toes 2, 3, and 4.
Bending or curvature of the distal phalanx of little finger in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger).
Absence or underdevelopment of the tibia.
Underdevelopment of both forearm bones, the ulna and the radius, resulting in a shortened forearm.

value: Absent fourth finger distal interphalangeal crease
definition: Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fourth finger.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.
An abnormal increase of bone mineral density with generalized involvement of the skeleton.

value: Cortical thickening of long bone diaphyses
definition: Abnormal thickening of the cortex of the diaphyseal region of long bones.
Underdevelopment of the humerus.

value: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the toes
definition: Abnormally short distal phalanx of toe of all toes.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an posterior direction.
Aplasia (absence) of the distal phalanges.
The presence of more than 12 rib pairs.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the foot on the lateral side (i.e., on the side of the little toe).
Short (hypoplastic) middle phalanx of finger, affecting one or more fingers.
Bending or curvature of a second toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.

value: obsolete Joint swelling onset late infancy
obsolete Joint dislocations in young adult
Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton

definition: An abnormally round shape of the middle phalanx of the finger.
Generalized deposition of calcium salts within the brain.
The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an ulnar direction.
In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or "false joint").
A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.

An enchondroma is a benign growth of cartilage that develops within the medullary cavity of bone. Enchondromatosis refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas, and this term refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas within the medulla of metaphyseal bone. Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins.
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae.
Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe.
Progressively worsening joint contractures.

value: Enlarged sagittal diameter of the cervical canal

definition: Multiple bent (flexed) finger joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Fusion of a metacarpal bone with the proximal phalanx of the finger distal to it across the corresponding metacarpophalangeal joint.

value: Absent ossification of cervical vertebral bodies
definition: A lack of bone mineralization of one or more body of cervical vertebra.
Absence of a digit or of one or more phalanges of a finger.
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the calvaria and the base of skull.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the forearm skeleton.
Duplication of the metacarpal I bones.

value: Radial deviation of thumb terminal phalanx

definition: Severe degree of osteoporosis.
Abnormal mineralization of the metaphyseal area of bones.
Presence of an angular or V -shaped indentation on the ulnar side of the fifth metacarpal bone (i.e., on the sides towards the fifth finger).
The presence of an abnormal curvature of the cervical vertebral column.

value: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
definition: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.

value: Rhomboid or triangular shaped 5th finger middle phalanx
definition: Rhomboid or triangular shaped 5th (little) finger middle phalanx.
Atresia of the biliary tree.
Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the metacarpal bones.
Irregularly shaped metacarpal bones of varying degree.
The presence of more than the normal number of metacarpal bones.
Abnormalities affecting the phalanx of finger.

value: Abnormal epiphysis morphology of the phalanges of the hand
definition: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand. Note that this includes the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).

value: obsolete Abnormal ossification of hand bones

definition: Any structural anomaly of the hand.

value: Abnormalities of the metaphyses of the hand
Abnormality of the epiphyses of the hand
definition: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the phalanges or metacarpal bones.

value: Abnormalities of the diaphyses of the hand

definition: An anomaly of the outer shell (cortex) of a hand bone.

value: Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the hand
definition: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the bones of the hand.

An anomaly of epiphysis, which is the expanded articular end of a long bone that developes from a secondary ossification center, and which during the period of growth is either entirely cartilaginous or is separated from the shaft by a cartilaginous disk.

An abnormality of corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) on diagnostic imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging, computer tomography, or sonography. CMD is a difference in the visualization of cortex and medulla.
Abnormal arrangement of the structures of the motile cilium.

Diffuse filling of the distal airsspaces of the lungs, the alveoli, with macrophages. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present.
Bilateral lack of development of the lungs.
Blockage of the upper airway at the level of the larynx often accompanied by respiratory distress.

value: Ventilator dependence with inability to wean

definition: Reduced tendency to respond to a reduced concentration of oxygen in the blood by increasing respiration.
The presence of multiple lung cysts.
Recurrent episodes of apnea occurring during infancy.
A membrane-like structure that extends across the laryngeal lumen close to the level of the vocal cords.
Abnormal shortening of the larynx in the anteroposterior (front to back) axis.
An impairment of gluconeogenesis.
A decreased concentration of arginine in the blood.
Episodes of reduced body termperature.
Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature.
Acidosis because of respiratory retention of carbon dioxide.

Reduced intestinal absorption of fructose. Breath testing after ingestion of fructose has been widely adopted as a standard method of identifying fructose malabsorption and intolerance. A dose of 25 g of fructose dissolved in a 10% solution is generally accepted as the appropriate dose of fructose for clinical use of H2 and CH4 breath testing. High levels of hydrogen in exhaled breath subsequent hours indicate fructose intolerance. Presence of malabsorption and reproduction of symptoms during a breath test provides the best objective evidence and symptom correlation for fructose intolerance.
Intermittent episodes of ketoacidosis.
A type of diabetes mellitus initially characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia and subsequently by glucose interolerance and hyperglycemia.
A metabolic acidosis due to accumulation of ketone bodies generally observed in the setting of poor nutritional intake.
A reduction in phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase level.
An elevation of alpha-feto protein in the maternal serum.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.
A congenital form of torticollis resulting from shortening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and leading to a limited range of motion in both rotation and lateral bending.
Excess skin around the neck, often lying in horizontal folds.
Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland.
Reduced abilty to lower the chin towards the chest by bending the neck.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to one or more nodules in the thyroid gland.
Reduced amount of adipose tissue in the region of the neck.

value: Restricted neck movement due to contractures

definition: A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter.
Obstruction of the flow of urine through the ureter.

value: Hypotrophy of the small hand muscles

definition: Increased side-to-side width of one or more phalanges of the fingers or toes.
Severely shortened metacarpal with a cuboidal appearance.
Delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more phalanx.
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the metacarpal bones.

Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones.
A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpal bones, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones.
A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.
Malalignement of carpal bone angles either with respect to each other, to the corresponding metacarpals or with respect to the wrist (radius and ulna).
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four.
Increased mobility of one ore more metacarpophalangeal joint.

Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers.
Metacarpal that becomes thinner toward the distal end.
Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers).

value: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the fingers
definition: Short, hypoplastic middle phalanx of finger, affecting all fingers.

value: Expanded phalanges with widened medullary cavities

definition: The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease).

value: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the fingers
definition: Hypoplasia of all of the distal phalanx of finger.
Some or all of the metacarpal bones (i.e., metacarpal II to V) have a pointed proximal appearance.
A type of digital ulcer that manifests as an open sore on the surface of the skin at the tip of a finger or toe.
Increased length of the proximal phalanx of finger.
Rounding and broadening of the tufts of the distal phalanges.
Abnormally large size of the metaphyseal epiphyses.
Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth.

value: Shortening of all proximal phalanges of the fingers
definition: Congenital hypoplasia of proximal phalanx of finger or all fingers.

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses.

value: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
definition: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke.

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.
Increased length of multiple or a single phalanx of finger.
Bending or curvature of a thumb towards the ulnar side (towards the ring finger).
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Irregular morphology of one or more metacarpal bones.

value: Short metacarpals with rounded proximal ends
Soft tissue swelling of interphalangeal joints

definition: A morphological abnormality of distal phalanges such that they have the appearance of chess pawns.

value: Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones

definition: Increase in bone density in the diaphyseal (shaft) region of a metacarpal bone.

value: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth

definition: Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases.
Excessively deep creases of the palm.
Phalanges of the fingers becoming thinner toward the distal end.
The middle phalanx of finger resembles a thimble, a small metal cap to protect the finger while sewing that has a broad (proximal) base and narrower top, whereby both base and top are flat.

value: Decreased movement range in interphalangeal joints

definition: Alteration of the normally smooth radiographic contour of phalanges producing an irregular appearance.

value: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of second finger
definition: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the second finger.
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the proximal phalanges.

value: Thin proximal phalanges with broad epiphyses of the hand
Single interphalangeal crease of fifth finger
definition: Presence of only one (instead of two, as normal) interphalangeal crease of the fifth finger.

value: Limited mobility of proximal interphalangeal joint
Tapering pointed ends of distal finger phalanges
definition: A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end such that the tip of the phalanx comes to a point (this feature can be observed on radiograms).

value: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities
Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint

definition: An increased resorption of bone matrix by osteoclasts leading to bony defects involving the tarsal bones.
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter).

value: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the toes
definition: Abnormal shortening of all middle phalanges of toes.
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the wrist.
An increased concentration of alpha-fetoprotein.

value: Abnormal phalangeal joint morphology of the hand

definition: A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 5th finger.

value: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger
definition: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the proximal, middle, and distal phalanges of the 2nd finger.
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 2nd finger.
Small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic fingers.
Reduced size of the placenta.
Increased size of the placenta.
Intermittently increased size of the spleen.
Underdevelopment of the spleen.
The presence of lymphangiectasis in the pancreas.
Reduced number of beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans.
Hyperplasia of the pancreas.
The presence of pancreatic tissue outside the normal pancreas, in many cases along the foregut and proximal midgut.
A chronic form of pancreatitis.
A generalized form of developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel.
The presence of multiple embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt.
A decreased amount of enamel mineralization. Hypomineralized enamel has a brown discoloration and brittle aspect.
Premature tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD earlier than the mean eruption age.
Agenesis of one or more central incisors, i.e., of lower secondary incisor, lower primary incisor, upper secondary incisor, or of upper central primary incisor.
The presence of discolored lateral incisors.

value: Marked delay in eruption of permanent teeth

definition: An abnormality of tooth eruption.
Agenesis of upper secondary incisor or of upper central primary incisor.
Developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel.
Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention.
Dagger-shaped calcifications in the dental pulp.
A generalized form of microdontia.
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia.
A single maxillary central incisor positioned in the midline with morphological symmetry of the crown and bordered by lateral incisors.
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth.
Loss of the primary (also known as deciduous) teeth before the usual age.
Underdevelopment of the alveolar process (also known as alveolar bone).
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, maxillary incisor, either the primary maxillary incisor or the permanent maxillary incisor.
A type of dental misalignment with crowded central incisors, i.e., of maxillary secondary incisor, or of maxillary central primary incisor.
Developmental hypoplasia of the primary teeth.
Persistence of the primary teeth beyond the age by which they normally are shed and replaced by the permanent teeth.
Tooth root length more than 2 SD below mean, or subjectively apparently decreased tooth root length.
Premature tooth eruption of the permanent dentition.
An abnormality of the morphology of secondary premolar tooth.
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary or permanent mandibular incisors.
A tooth crown with its mesial and distal sides converging or tapering toward the incisal edge causing severe reduction of mesiodistal diameter
An abnormality of morphology of primary molar.
