definition: The presence of intracellular inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in neutrophils. Cytoplasmic neutrophil inclusions (oval, basophilic) are also known as Doehle bodies.

value: Increased red cell hemolysis by shear stress

definition: Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. A number of abnormalities may be appreciated by electron micrography or biochemical investigations, including sparse collagen fibers in the cartilage matrix.
An abnormality of zinc ion homeostasis.
Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellar cortex.
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood with sudden onset.
An increased amount of unconjugated (indirect) bilurubin in the blood.
An increased concentration of insulin in the blood in the fasting state, i.e., not as the response to food intake.
A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).
An increase in the level of long-chain dicarboxylic acid in the urine.

A condition of not having consistently high levels of phenylalanine in the blood but of experiencing temporary hyperphenylalaninemia following ingestion of large quantities of phenylalanine (for instance, following an oral loading test with phenylalanine).
An increased concentration of dermatan sulfate in the urine.
Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata.
Presence of myoglobin in the urine following exercise.
An increase in the level of medium chain dicarboxylic acid in the urine.

value: Spinal cord posterior columns myelin loss
Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex II
definition: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex II, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.
A decreased concentration of free (unbound) carnitine in the blood.
An abnormality of the mitochondria in muscle tissue.
Increased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes.
Abnormal response to collagen or collagen-mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition collagen or collagen-mimetics.

Reduced activity of coagulation factor X. The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways converge at factor X (fX). The extrinsic pathway activates fX by means of d factor VII with its cofactor, tissue factor. The intrinsic pathway activates fX by means of the tenase complex (Ca2+ and factors VIIIa, IXa and X) on the surface of activated platelets. Factor Xa in turn activates prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin (factor IIa).
Any structural anomaly of the mitochondria.
An abnormality of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram.
An abnormally decreased concentration of vitamin B6 in the blood circulation.
The presence of microscopic crystalline calcium precipitates in the form of oxalate and/or phosphate in the renal parenchyma.
Decreased activity of von Willebrand factor. Von Willebrand factor mediates the adhesion of platelets to the collagen exposed on endothelial cell surfaces.

value: Partial functional complement factor D deficiency
definition: A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor D in circulation.
An increased urine level of any amino acid carrying two amino groups (Asparagine, glutamine and lysine, cystine, ornithine).

A type of renal tubular acidosis characterized by a failure of acid secretion by the alpha intercalated cells of the cortical collecting duct of the distal nephron. The urine cannot be acidified below a pH of 5.3, associated with acidemia and hypokalemia.

value: Elevated plasma branched chain amino acids
definition: An increased concentration of a branched chain amino acid in the blood.

value: Hypoplasia of the iris dilator muscle
definition: Underdevelopment of the dilatator pupillae.

value: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex IV
definition: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.
A reduction in immunoglobulin levels of the IgG2 subclass in the blood circulation.

An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation.

The presence of an abnormally increased concentration of neutral amino acids in the urine. The neutral amino acids are tryptophan, alanine, asparagine, glutamine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, phenylalanine, serine, threonine, tyrosine and valine.
Reduced ability to transform factor X into its activated form factor Xa.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor XIII (also known as fibrin stabilizing factor). Activated Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers solidifying the clot.
An increased concentration of proline in the blood.
A neonatal decreased concentration of proteins in the blood.
Absence or underdevelopment of the big toe.
Absence or underdevelopment of the tarsal bones.
An abnormality of the calcaneus, also known as the heel bone, one of the or heel bone, one of the components of the tarsus of the foot which make up the heel.
An abnormality of the talus.

value: Contractures involving the joints of the feet

definition: Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the tarsus (calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, cuneiiform bones).
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.

Any abnormal process of ossification of the metatarsal bones, which normally are each ossified from two centers: one for the body, and one for the head (metatarsal II,III,IV, and V) and one for the body and one for the base (metatarsal I). The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years.
Nails whose growth is slower than normal.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the nail.
An anomaly of the toenail.

value: Recurrent loss of toenails and fingernails
definition: Repeated loss, or shedding, of the nails of the fingers and toes.
The presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, often with accumulation of soft, yellow keratin between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed, resulting in elevation of the nail plate.
A thickening of the stratum corneum in the region beneath the nails.

value: Congenital curved nail of fourth toe

definition: Chronic infection of the nails by Candida species.
A nail of the fifth finger that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail of little finger.
A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails.
Detachment of the distal fingernails from the nail bed.
Thickened toenails.
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the fingernail plate.

Onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) refers to nail changes apart from changes of the color (nail dyschromia) and involves partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
Small, underdeveloped vertebral bodies.
The presence of degenerative changes of intervertebral disk.
The presence of punctiform calcification of the bone of the vertebral bodies.
An abnormal shape of the vertebral bodies whereby the vertebral bodies are thick on one side and taper to a thin edge at the other.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the vertebral column.
Schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies of the lumbar spine.
An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L1 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).

value: Absent in utero ossification of vertebral bodies

definition: A morphological abnormality of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine.
Any abnormality of the atlas and the axis.
The presence of one or more herniated nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disk.
Excessive growth of the bones of the vertebral bodies.
An abnormality of the shape of vertebrae, such that they are wedge-shaped (narrow towards the back).
An abnormal narrowing of the cervical spinal canal.

A reduction of the distance between vertebral pedicles, which are the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the vertebral body, at the junction of its posterior and lateral surfaces.
Over curvature of the lumbar region.

A developmental defect of the sacrum characterized by partial or disordered development of the sacrum in which portions of the sacrum, which normally is formed by fusion of five sacral vertebrae S1-S5, fail to form or fail to form normally.
A partial dislocation of the intervertebral joint between the second and third cervical vertebrae.

Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column. Note that normally, the interpedicular distances get progressively wider as one proceeds down the spine.
A progressive form of scoliosis with congenital onset.
Agenesis of one or more vertebrae of the cervical vertebral column.

value: Absent spinous processes of lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae

definition: A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the thoracic spine.
An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of sacral vertebrae during development.
Dysplasia of the cervical vertebral column.
A reduction of the distance between the lower thoracic vertebral pedicles.
An abnormal reduction of the anterioposterior diameter of the vertebral body.
Decreased ossification of the cervical vertebral bodies, i.e., of the Cervical vertebrae set.
The presence of arthrosis, i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the cervical vertebral column.

value: Cervical vertebral bodies with decreased anteroposterior diameter

definition: A reduction of the distance between thoracolumbar vertebral pedicles.
Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between lumbar vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column.
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the fifth lumbar vertebral body (L5) onto the sacrum (level S1).
Early closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.
Partial displacement of the lens in the inferior direction.
A severe form of hypermetropia with over +5.00 diopters.
Cleft lip or palate affecting the midline region of the palate.
The presence of a moderate form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
Reduced transparency of the central posterior portion of the corneal stroma.
A bilateral type of conductive hearing impairment.

value: Abnormality of the vertebral spinous processes

definition: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the sacral bone.
Any structural abnormality of the coccyx.
Permanent indentation on the posteromedial aspect of the helix that may be sharply or indistinctly delineated.
A type of hearing impairment caused by an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve with congenital onset.

value: Long hairs growing from helix of pinna

definition: Absence of the acoustic reflex, an involuntary contraction of the stapedius muscle that occurs in response to high-intensity sound stimuli.

value: Cleft at the superior portion of the pinna

definition: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the low frequencies of sound (125 Hz to 1000 Hz).
Underdevelopment of the external ear.
The presence of a malformed cochlea.
Complete lack of functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
Vestibular areflexia can be measured as the absence of the caloric nystagmus response in electronystagmography.
Median longitudinal length of the ear more than two standard deviations below the mean in the presence of some, but not all, parts of the normal ear.
A malformation of the auricle of the ear.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the lower frequencies.
Underdevelopment of the helix that either affects the entire helix, or is localized.
A condition in which the superior portion of the helix is folded over to a lesser degree than normal.
Developmental hypoplasia of the cochlea.
The presence of a mild form of sensorineural hearing impairment.

value: Slit-like opening of the exterior auditory meatus
definition: A type of stenosis of the external auditory meatus in which the opening of the external auditory meatus appears as a vertical slit.
Underdevelopment of the helix, i.e., of the outer rim of the pinna.
A type of conductive deafness with congenital onset.
Increased anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with onset after the acquisition of speech.
A mild form of conductive hearing impairment.
Benign congenital lesion of the supraauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
A progressive type of conductive deafness.

value: Morphological abnormality of the middle ear
definition: An abnormality of the morphology or structure of the middle ear.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with infantile onset.
The presence of sensorineural deafness with late onset.
A bilateral form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
A severe form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
An abnormality of the stapes, a stirrup-shaped ossicle in the middle ear.

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation.
A developmental anomaly of the ureter.
Absence of sex glands (gonads are the organs that produce gametes; testis in males and ovary in females).
Abnormal enlargement of the urinary bladder.

Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney. Nephroblastomatosis represents a complex abnormality of nephrogenesis and has been defined as the persistence of metanephricblastema into infancy and childhood.

value: Uric acid urolithiasis independent of gout

definition: Impotence (inability to develop or maintain an erection) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
A type of extracapillary glomerulonephritis characterized by the formation of crescent-like cellular proliferation.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the fallopian tube.
The presence of many cysts in the medulla of the kidney.
A developmental defect characterized by absence or poor development of proximal renal tubules.
Abnormal narrowing of the urethra.
A sarcoma of the kidney.
Hypertrophy of the clitoris.
Unusual gonadal development in a person with a 46,XY male karyotype, leading to an unassigned sex differentiation.
Incomplete maturation or aberrant formation of the male gametes.
The presence of calcium- and oxalate-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
A developmental disturbance with extreme ureteral dilatation.
Nephrotic syndrome with onset within the first three months of life.
Absence or underdevelopment of the kidney.

Coagulative necrosis of tubular epithelial cells, defined as cells with increased cytoplasmic eosinophilia and nucleus that has a condensed chromatin pattern with fuzzy nuclear contour or has barely visible nuclear basophilic staining. The extent of cortical tubular necrosis is scoredsemiquantitatively as none, mild (less than 25% tubules with necrosis), moderate (25-50 percent), and severe (over 50%).
Increase in size of the folds of skin between the outer labia.
Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the uterus.
Absence of both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
Presence of a single diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that are native to the kidneys.
Developmental hypoplasia of the fallopian tube.
Deposition of calcium salts in gonadal tissue.
Congenital absence of the scrotum.

value: Partial development of the penile shaft

definition: The presence of non-malignant hyperplasia of the prostate.
The presence of a fistula between the vagina and the urethra.
A unilateral form of atrophy of the kidney.
A unilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
The presence of a diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urethra.

value: Gonadal dysgenesis with female appearance, male
definition: Unusual gonadal development in a person with a 46,XY male karyotype, leading to a more female sex differentiation.
Developmental hypoplasia of the ovary.
Developmental hypoplasia of the vagina.

value: Female external genitalia in individual with 46,XY karyotype
definition: The presence of female external genitalia in a person with a male karyotype.
Renal hypophosphatemia is defined as reduced serum phosphate (e.g., below 0.70 mmol/l) and an inappropriately high renal phosphate excretion.
Reduced volume of the testicle (the male gonad).
The presence of a partially duplicated kidney.
The presence of a longitudinal vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication.
A mild form of hypospadias in which the urethra opens just under the corona glandis.
An abnormality of the aryepiglottic fold.
Ossification affecting the set of cartilages of larynx.
Underdevelopment of the larynx.
Congenital absence of the lumen of the larynx.
Presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus.
A malformation of the laryngeal cartilage.
Absence of the epiglottis.
Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the laryngeal tissues.
Bowing (abnormal curvature) of the vocal folds.
A loss of the ability to move the vocal fold on one side.
The false perception of sound.

value: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements

definition: The presence of one or more obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Obsessions refer to persistent intrusive thoughts, and compulsions to intrusive behaviors, which the affected person experiences as involuntary, senseless, or repugnant.
The presence of aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ear.
The presence of aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of all or part of the external ear.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of all or part of the middle ear.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the inner ear.
An abnormality of the prostate.
Any structural abnormality of the renal artery.
An abnormality of the vocal cord.
Increased width of the proximal part of the shaft (metaphysis) of the femur.
Abnormally wide morphology of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the rami (branches) of the pubic bone.
Irregularities of the iliac crest that produce the appearance of a lace border around it.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the pubic bone.
A cone-shaped deformity of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
A general term that describes a congenital defect in the iliac wing resulting from abnormal development.

value: Early ossification of capital femoral epiphyses
definition: Developmental acceleration of ossification of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.

The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a increase in the lateral dimension of the notch.
A decreased ability to move the femur at the hip joint associated with a decreased range of motion of the hip.
Underdevelopment of the lesser trochanter.
Underdevelopment of the femoral head.
Increased width of the femoral head.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the acetabular part of hip bone.
Increased height of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
An abnormally flattened femoral head.
Increased size of the ilium ala.
An abnormally reduced diameter of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).

value: Absent ossification of capital femoral epiphysis
definition: Lack of ossification of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
Underdevelopment of the ischiopubic ramus, which is comprised of the inferior pubic ramus and the inferior ramus of the ischium.
Underdevelopment of the body of ilium.
Joint dislocation of the femoral head.
Developmental delay of ossification of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
Delayed ossification of the femoral head.
There is normally one ossification center in the head of the femur. This term applies if there are multiple such centers.
Underdevelopment of the bony pelvis.
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by disproportionate shortening of the medial parts of the extremities (forearm or lower leg).
Intrauterine growth retardation that is 4 or more standard deviations below average, corrected for sex and gestational age.
A moderate degree of short stature, more than -3 SD but not more than -4 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
Severely slow or limited growth after birth, being four standard deviations or more below age- and sex-related norms.
A moderate degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between three and four standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms.
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with congenital onset recognizable at birth.

value: Failure to thrive secondary to recurrent infections
definition: Insufficient weight gain or inappropriate weight loss for a child, that is attributed to an endogenous recurrent infections.

Impaired feeding performance of an infant as manifested by difficulties such as weak and ineffective sucking, brief bursts of sucking, and falling asleep during sucking. There may be difficulties with chewing or maintaining attention.
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short limbs but an average-sized trunk.
Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 2 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 3 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.
A loss of adipose tissue.
Slow or limited growth after birth.
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of limbs (i.e. the femur and humerus).
Truncal obesity with onset during childhood, defined as between 2 and 10 years of age.
A type of short-limbed dwarfism that is manifest beginning in the neonatal period.

Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the arms.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the shoulder.
Underdevelopment of the pectoralis major.
Atrophy of the intrinsic muscle groups of the hand, comprising the thenar and hypothenar muscles; the interossei muscles; and the lumbrical muscles.
Progressive muscular atrophy affecting muscles in the distal portions of the extremities.

Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms.
Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf.

An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue.

The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.
Underdevelopment of the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension, internal rotation, and transverse extension of the shoulder and assists in movement of the scapula.

Weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot, that is, of the movement of the toes towards the shin. The foot dorsiflexors include the tibialis anterior, the extensor hallucis longus, the extensor digitorum longus, and the peroneus tertius muscles.

Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature.

value: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the little finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx.

definition: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.

A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis. The normal metacarpal epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones. Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone.

value: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the ring finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat.

Displacement of the 4th finger from its normal position.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 4th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.

value: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

value: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. That is, the PIP joint of a fourth finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.

value: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 4th finger
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

Absent 4th finger.

definition: An abnormality of the middle phalanx of the third finger in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side.

value: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx.

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.
A bilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
A unilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain.
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma.
The presence of a peripheral schwannoma.
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.
Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.

Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the proximal, and distal phalanges of the thumb and/or the 1st metacarpal.
Chronic loss of joint motion in the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
Hypoplastic/small or absent thumb.
A structural anomaly of one or more phalanges of the thumb.
Displacement of the thumb from its normal position.

value: Complete duplication of distal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side.

value: Complete duplication of proximal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
Partail or complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone.

value: Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

value: Bifid proximal phalanx of the thumb
definition: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is partially duplicated. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

value: Complete duplication of the first metacarpal
definition: Complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone.
Partial duplication of the first metacarpal bone.

value: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb
definition: Any anomaly of the distal phalanx of thumb.

value: Abnormality of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
definition: An anomaly of the shape or form of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.

value: obsolete Radial deviation of the thumb
obsolete Ulnar deviation of the thumb

definition: Insertion of thumb at a more distal location than normal.
Proximal mislocalization of the thumb.

value: Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is formed by the first metacarpal and the trapezial bone and is also called Articulatio carpometacarpalis pollicis, carpometacarpal articulation of thumb, carpometacarpal joint of thumb or first carpometacarpal articulation. Seldom referred to as thumb saddle joint.

value: Contractures of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio metacarpophalangealis pollicis.

value: Contractures of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio interphalangealis pollicis.

value: Broad proximal phalanx of the thumb

definition: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat.
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the thumb.
An abnormality of the thumb in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side.

A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the thumb, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx.
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms.
Epiphysis of the thumb having multiple bony fragments.
Uneven radiographic opacity of the one or more epiphyses of the thumb.
Sclerosis of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of one or more phalanges of the thumb.
Abnormally small size of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb.

value: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion in one or more distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

value: Osteolytic defects of the hand bones

definition: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term "symphalangism of the hand" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are referred to as "Symphalangism" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly.

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).

Fusion of the 1st metacarpal with another bone. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2 to 5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter.
Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks.
A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics.
A hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord.
An abnormality of the epididymis.
A cystadenoma, an epithelial tumor, that originates within the head of the epididymis.
Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis.

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.

A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots") are white or lighter patches of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by a lack of melanin. White ash leaf-shaped macules are considered to be characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.
The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin.

A plaque representing a connective-tissue nevus. Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. Shagreen patches are oval-shaped and nevoid, skin-colored or occasionally pigmented, smooth or crinkled, The word shagreen refers to a type of roughened untanned leather.
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel.
A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail.
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder.
The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney.
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina.
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle.
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle.
A benign tumor of striated muscle.
The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum.
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure.
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm.
Neurofibromas originating in the spine.

Pseudarthrosis, or "false joint" of the tibia is the result of a developmental failure in the tibia progressing to spontaneous fracture and subsequent fibrous nonunion. The fracture is rarely present at birth but commonly develops during the first 18 months of life.
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris..
An abnormality of the antihelix.
Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix.
Absence of the parotid gland.
Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring ("sclerosis") resulting from damage to the renal arterioles, also referred to as arteriosclerosis of the kidney arteries.
Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
Double rows of eyelashes.
An abnormality of the spinal dura mater, which is the outermost of the three layers of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord.
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum.
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.
Increased volume of the earlobe, that is, abnormally prominent ear lobules.

value: Aplasia of the pectoralis major muscle
definition: Absence of the pectoralis major muscle.
A bony defect in the skull base.
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue.
A pterygium (or pterygia) occurring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region.

value: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails
definition: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails is a rare and distinctive anomaly seen in popliteal pterygia syndrome.
Pterygia affecting the neck.
Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric.
Anterior schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.
Columella extending inferior to the level of the nasal base, when viewed from the side.

value: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the hand
definition: Small or missing phalangeal bones of the fingers of the hand.
Increased width of the phalanges of the hand.
The presence of short and wide phalanges which taper distally ("bullet shaped").

value: Osteolytic defects of the phalanges of the hand
definition: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the phalanges of the hand.
Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of one or more of the phalanges of the hand.

value: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the hand
definition: Fusion of two or more phalangeal bones of the hand.

value: Triangular shaped phalanges of the hand

definition: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues.
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues.
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four.

Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic.
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
Absence or underdevelopment of the biceps muscle.
Absence of the biceps muscle.
Absence or underdevelopment of the triceps muscle.
Absence of the triceps muscle.

value: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the musculature of the thigh
definition: Absence or underdevelopment involving the musculature of the thigh.
Absence or underdevelopment of the quadriceps muscle.
Absence of the quadriceps muscle.
The presence of an abscess located around the anus.
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5.
Presence of a bifid sacral bone.
The presence of a teratoma.
A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma located anterior to the sacrum and entirely inside the body (Altman type IV).
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region.

Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear.
A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities.
The presence of two or more accessory spleens.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.

value: Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
definition: Absence of one or more of the phalanges of the hand.
Short (hypoplastic) phalanx of finger, affecting one or more phalanges.

The absence of one or more teeth from the normal series by a failure
to develop
A form of heart failure characterized by reduced cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure owing to ischemic heart disease, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, and other causes.
A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP).

value: Anomaly of the upper limb diaphyses
definition: A structural abnormality of a diaphysis of the arm.
An anomaly of one or more metaphyses of the arms.
An anomaly of the joint that connects the upper and the lower arm.
Amelia of one or both upper limbs.

Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation.
Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the extremities.
Leg shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the lower extremity.

value: Aplasia involving bones of the lower limbs

definition: Amelia of one or both legs.
Phocomelia affecting only the lower limbs.
Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.
Forearm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the forearm.

value: Aplasia involving bones of the upper limbs

definition: Arm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the upper extremity.

value: Aplasia involving bones of the extremities

definition: Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities.
Congenital absence (aplasia) of one or more limbs.
The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation.

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).

Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.
A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution.

value: Abnormal distal phalanx morphology of finger
definition: Any anomaly of distal phalanx of finger.

value: Abnormal middle phalanx morphology of the hand
definition: An anomaly of middle phalanx of finger.

value: Abnormal proximal phalanx morphology of the hand
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges of the hand
definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the distal phalanges.
Abnormally wide (broad) distal phalanx of finger.

value: Bullet-shaped distal phalanges of the hand
definition: Short and wide distal phalanges that taper distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

value: Curved distal phalanges of the hand
Osteolytic defects of the distal phalanges of the hand
Patchy sclerosis of distal phalanx of finger
definition: Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of the distal phalanges of the hand.

value: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle phalanges of the hand

definition: Increased width of the middle phalanx of finger.

value: Bullet-shaped middle phalanges of the hand
definition: Any of the middle phalanges with short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

value: Curved middle phalanges of the hand
Osteolytic defects of the middle phalanges of the hand
Patchy sclerosis of middle phalanx of finger
definition: Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand.

value: Symphalangism of middle phalanx of finger
definition: Fusion of a middle phalanx of a finger with another bone.

value: Triangular shaped middle phalanges of the hand
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the proximal phalanges of the hand
Broad proximal phalanges of the hand
definition: Increased width of the proximal phalanges of the finger.

value: Bullet-shaped proximal phalanges of the hand
definition: Short and wide proximal phalanges that taper distally . Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

value: Curved proximal phalanges of the hand
Osteolytic defects of the proximal phalanges of the hand
Patchy sclerosis of proximal phalanx of finger
definition: Uneven increase in bone density of the proximal phalanges of the hand.

value: Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanges of the hand
Triangular shaped proximal phalanges of the hand
Triangular shaped distal phalanges of the hand
Cerebellar ataxia associated with quadrupedal gait
definition: The presence of cerebellar signs and symptoms such as lack of balance associated with quadrupedal gait (locomotion on all four extremities with a 'bear-like' gait with the legs held straight).
An abnormality of the cerebral cortex with fewer gyri but with normal cortical thickness. This pattern is usually often associated with congenital microcephaly.

value: Broad distal phalanges of all fingers
definition: Abnormally wide (broad) distal phalanx of finger of all fingers.

value: Aplasia of the distal phalanges of the hand

definition: Short distance from the end of the finger to the most distal interphalangeal crease or the distal interphalangeal joint flexion point. That is, hypoplasia of one or more of the distal phalanx of finger.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of hand
definition: This term applies if one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.
An abnormality of hair pigmentation (color).

Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair.
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
Complete absence of any auricular structures.
The presence of telangiectasia of the ear.
Increased thickness of the external ear.

value: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
definition: An abnormality of the crus of the helix, which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear.
An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch.

An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix. That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly.
Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix. That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average.
The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix. That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix.
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound.
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds.
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length.
Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye.
Abnormally prominent ear helix.
Decreased thickness of the helix of the ear.
Absence or underdevelopment of the ear lobes.
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward.
Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe.
An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly.

value: Aplasia of the middle ear ossicles
definition: Absence of the middle ear ossicles, malleus, incus, and stapes.
Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple.
An abnormality of the tragus.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the tragus.
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea.
Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease.
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.
A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris.
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina.
A dermal melanocytic hamartoma that presents as bluish hyperpigmentation on the face along the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Nevus of Ota may involve the sclera.
A condition associated with a limitation of the horizontal ocular movement with retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction

value: Vascular remnant arising from the disc
definition: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth.
Underdevelopment or absence of the nose or parts thereof.
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).
Complete absence of all nasal structures.
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi.
An abnormality of the columella.
Asymmetry or size difference between the left and right nostril.
Increased aperture of the nostril.
The presence of only a single nostril.
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril.
The presence of more than two nostrils.
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
Abnormally narrow nasal septum.
Excess facial hair.
Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible.
Absence of the mandible.
Lack of symmetry between the left and right mandible.
The presence of an asymmetric mouth.

Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the second proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of index finger.

value: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the middle phalanx of index finger.

value: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of index finger.

value: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of index finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of index finger.

value: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of index finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the second proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the second proximal phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd finger
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd finger
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 3rd finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 3rd finger
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 3rd finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

value: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 3rd finger
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 3rd finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of middle finger.

value: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the middle phalanx of middle finger.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the third proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of middle finger

value: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of middle finger.

value: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Complete duplication of the third proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of middle finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of middle finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
definition: Partial duplication of the third proximal phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 4th finger
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

value: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 4th finger
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of ring finger.

value: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the middle phalanx of ring finger.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the fourth proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of ring finger.

value: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of ring finger.

value: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the fourth proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of ring finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of ring finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
definition: Partial duplication of the fourth proximal phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 5th finger
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

value: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 5th finger
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of little finger.

value: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the fifth middle phalanx of hand.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the fifth proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of little finger.

value: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the fifth middle phalanx of hand.

value: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Complete duplication of the fifth proximal phalanx of hand.

value: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of little finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial duplication of the fifth middle phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

value: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
definition: Partial or complete duplication of the fifth proximal phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.
This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Complete duplication of phalanx of hand
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

value: Partial duplication of the phalanx of hand
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanges of the hand
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the proximal phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

value: Complete duplication of the distal phalanges of the hand
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand.

value: Complete duplication of the middle phalanges of the hand
definition: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accessory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a pseudoepiphysis (see corresponding terms) sometimes also referred to as hyperphalangism.

value: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanges of the hand
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the proximal phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Partial duplication of the distal phalanges of the hand
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Partial duplication of the middle phalanges of the hand
definition: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

value: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of hand
definition: This term applies if one or more of the proximal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

value: Duplication of the middle phalanx of hand
definition: This term applies if one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
A structural anomaly of the first metacarpal.
Any abnormality of the second metacarpal bone.
Any abnormality of the third metacarpal bone.
Any abnormality of the fourth metacarpal bone.
Any abnormality of the fifth metacarpal bone.

value: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
definition: In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits). The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end (as seen in the proximal phalanges of the other digits), whereas the epiphyses of the other metacarpal bones are located at the distal end. This term applies if the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal is in any way abnormal, referring to age and gender depending norms, as seen on x-rays.

An epiphysis that curves around from its transverse orientation to a longitudinal one from proximal to distal along one side of the phalanx, thus resembling the letter 'C' and forming a bracket around the diaphysis. This results in a so called delta phalanx characterized by a triangular or trapezoidal shaped bone with a C-shaped epiphyseal plate.
A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance.
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms.

value: Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
definition: Epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal having multiple bony fragments.
Uneven radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal.
The epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.
The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone although an accessory epiphysis may be located at the distal end of the metacarpal.
Abnormally small size of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms.

value: Epiphyseal stippling of the first metacarpal
definition: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphyses of the first metacarpal bone.

Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).

Increased width of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
The presence of short and wide 1st metacarpal which tapers distally ("bullet shaped").
A deviation from the normal straight shape of the first metacarpal.
Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the 1st metacarpal.
Uneven increase in bone density within the 1st metacarpal.
This term applies to a triangular shaped 1st metacarpal.
A developmental defect characterized by reduced length of the first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Absent first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 2nd metacarpal.
Absence of the second long bone of the hand.
Short second metacarpal bone because of developmental hypoplasia.
Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 3rd metacarpal.
Absence of the third long bone of the hand.
Short third metacarpal bone.
Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 4th metacarpal.
Absence of the fourth long bone of the hand.
Short fourth metacarpal bone.
Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 5th metacarpal.
Absence of the fifth long bone of the hand.
Short fifth metacarpal bone.
Developmental defect associated with absence of one or more metacarpal bones.
Diminished length of one or more metacarpal bones in relation to the others of the same hand or to the contralateral metacarpal.
Displacement of the big toe from its normal position.

value: Abnormal morphology of the proximal phalanx of the hallux
definition: An abnormal shape or form of the proximal phalanx of the big toe.

value: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the hallux
Abnormality of the first metatarsal bone

value: Contracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux
definition: Chronic loss of joint motion in the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The tarsometatarsal joints of the feet are also called Lisfranc's joints.

definition: The interphalangeal joint of the big toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

value: Contractures of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the hallux
