definition: Contractures of one ore more joints of the feet meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
A decreased concentration of ammonia in the blood.

Any structural anomaly of mast cells, which are found in almost all tissues and contain numerous basophilic granules and are capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation.
The presence of an increased number of mast cells and CD34+ mast cell precursors in the body.

value: Abnormality of the vitamin B3 metabolism

definition: An increased susceptibility to bronchiolitis as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchiolitis.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B1.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B2.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B5.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B8.
A reduced circulating concentration of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9.
An anomaly in the metabolism of a vitamin.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin C.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin D.
A reduced concentration of vitamin E in the blood circulation. Vitamin E is a lipophilic vitamin that is also known as alpha-tocopherol.
Increased frequency of urination.
The presence of a neoplasm of the ureter.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urethra.
Painful or difficult urination.
Absence of urine, clinically classified as below 50ml/day.
Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thymus.
A tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus.
The presence of an abscess of the liver.
Congenital duplication of all or part of a limb.
Persistence of the urachal canal with drainage of urine from the bladder through the persistent allantois canal to the umbilicus.
Tumor of the lung.
A rare cancer originating in the lung or pleural cavity that occurs most often in infants and young children but also has been reported in adults. Pleuropulmonary blastoma is regarded as malignant.
An abnormality of phosphate homeostasis or concentration in the body.
Any deviation from the normal concentration in the blood circulation of a hormone that is involved in the regulation of phosphate and calcium.
The appearance of abnormal valgus deformity in one knee in association with varus deformity in the other.
Inflammation of the sclera.
Inflammation of the eye, parts of the eye or the periorbital region.
Inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
An abnormality of fascia.
Inflammation of fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle.
An anomaly of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
Edema affecting the region situated around the orbit of the eye.
Edema in the region of the eyelids.
A hernia which occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where abdominal contents pass through a naturally occurring weakness called the femoral canal.
An abnormal site of the kidney.
Abnormal cognition with deficits in thinking, reasoning, or remembering.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the heart.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of an artery.
Narrowing of the carotid arteries.
An abnormality of the forebrain, which has as its parts the telencephalon, diencephalon, lateral ventricles and third ventricle.
Eversion of a hollow organ and exposure, inside out, and protruded through the abdominal wall.
Breakage (tear) of a tendon.
A neoplasm of the trachea.
Overgrowth of only one leg.
Overgrowth of only one arm.
A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.
Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of a leg.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of an arm.
A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
Difference in length or size between the right and left arm.
Duplication of the spinal cord.
Coexistence of two hemicords, at variable levels, causing splaying of the posterior vertebral elements. Results in neurological deficits in lower limb or perineum.
Triplication of the spinal cord - extremely rare.
Dilation of central canal from incomplete fusion of the posterior columns or persistence of the primitive large canal of the embryo.
Congenital absence of the spinal cord.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the endocrine system.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of one or more vertebrae.
A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
A cardiac diverticulum is a rare congenital malformation which is either fibrous or muscular.
A fibrous cardiac diverticulum refers to an aneurysm and usually appears as an isolated congenital anomaly.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the biliary system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the gallbladder.
A transient visual disturbance that is typically caused by a circulatory, ocular or neurological underlying condition.
Inflammation of the urinary bladder.
Localized loss of fat tissue.
Telangiectasia of the mucosa, the mucous membranes which are involved in absorption and secretion that line cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs.

An abnormal change (metaplasia) in the cells of the inferior portion of the esophagus. The normal squamous epithelium lining of the esophagus is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Columnar epithelium refers to a cell type that is typically found in more distal parts of the gastrointestinal system.
An abnormal enlargement of the renal calices, the system of ducts of the kidney that collect urine.

Polypoidal masses arising mainly from the mucous membranes of the nose and paranasal sinuses. They are freely movable and nontender overgrowths of the mucosa that frequently accompany allergic rhinitis.
A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
An inflammation of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
Presence of small, permanently dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin, visible as small focal red lesions.
Patients who routinely have greater than 20 leukocytes per microliter, but have abacterial urine, are said to have sterile pyuria.
An abnormality of the retractable fold of skin that covers the tip of the penis.
The foreskin becomes trapped behind the glans penis, and cannot be pulled back to its normal flaccid position covering the glans penis.
The presence of a fistula affecting the genitourinary system.
The presence of a fistula affecting the rectum.
The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum.

Thin (2-3mm) membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa that can be congenital or acquired. Congenital webs commonly appear in the middle and inferior third of the esophagus, and they are more likely to be circumferential with a central or eccentric orifice. Acquired webs are much more common than congenital webs and typically appear in the cervical area (postcricoid). Clinical symptoms of this condition are selective (solid more than liquids) dysphagia, thoracic pain, nasopharyngeal reflux, aspiration, perforation and food impaction (the last two are very rare).

An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
The nostrils (the paired channels of the nose) are not present.
Fluid accumulation in the lungs.
Two penile structures, separated from the tip to the base of the shaft.
A partial or complete positional exchange between the penis and the scrotum, with positioning of the scrotum superior to the penis.

An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.
Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.
Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight Maternal hypertension or as life threatening as Eclampsia.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the lip.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the respiratory system.
Pain during menstruation that interferes with daily activities.
Bleeding at irregular intervals.
A medical history of exposure during the fetal period to hyperphenylalaninemia because the mother had phenylketonuria with inadequate control during pregnancy.
The presence of many cysts in the glomerulus of the kidney related to dilatation of the Bowman's capsule.
Neoplasm involving odontogenic cells, an odontogenic tumor.
Death between the age of 16 and 40 years.
A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ovary.
The presence of a teratoma of the testis.
The presence of a seminoma, an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the testis.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Leydig cell.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Sertoli cell.
A type of undifferentiated germ cell tumor that may be benign or malignant.
The presence of a dysgerminoma, i.e., an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the ovary.
A seizure during pregnancy.

A displacement of the external urethral orifice from its normal position (in males normally placed at the tip of glans penis, in females normally placed about 2.5 cm behind the glans clitoridis and immediately in front of that of the vagina).
The presence of a diverticulum of the esophagus.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the midline of the face.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adrenal gland.

The presence of a piece lung tissue which is not attached to the pulmonary blood supply and does not communicate with the other lung tissue (not connected to the standard bronchial airways and not performing a function in respiration).
Inflammation of the esophagus.
A tumor that originates from a neuroendocrine cell.
A paraganglioma (a neuroendocrine neoplasm) originating in a carotid artery.
A rare paranglioma of the lung, tumors that arise from extra-adrenal chromaffin cells.
A neoplasm originating in the pharynx.
A multidimensional but common male sexual dysfunction that involves an alteration in any of the components of the erectile response, including organic, relational and psychological.
Presence of a cyst (sac-like structure) located in the larynx.
The presence of a neoplasm of the adrenal cortex.
The presence of a neoplasm of the adrenal medulla.
An anomaly of the color of the nail.
Brown or black discoloration of the nails.
Anterior vaginal wall prolapse with bulging of the bladder into the vagina.
Inflammation of the thyroid gland.

An autoimmune disease where the thyroid is overactive, producing an excessive amount of thyroid hormones (a serious metabolic imbalance known as hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis). This is caused by autoantibodies to the TSH-receptor (TSHR-Ab) that activate that TSH-receptor (TSHR), thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, and thyroid growth (causing a diffusely enlarged goiter). The resulting state of hyperthyroidism can cause a dramatic constellation of neuropsychological and physical signs and symptoms, which can severely compromise the patients.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the tongue.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the oral cavity.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the vagina.

A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin. Type I diabetes mellitus is manifested by the sudden onset of severe hyperglycemia with rapid progression to diabetic ketoacidosis unless treated with insulin.
Inflammation of the optic nerve.
Optic neuritis that occurs in the section of the optic nerve located behind the eyeball.
Failure to close of the chest and abdominal wall likely caused by the failure of the ventral wall to close during week 4 of development.
Congenital protrusion of the abdominal or thoracic viscera, usually with a defect of the sternum and ribs as well as of the abdominal walls.
A bacterial infection and inflammation of the skin und subcutaneous tissues.
An anomaly of the cerebral blood vessels.
A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.
A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.
Inflammation of cartilage.
A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw.

Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication the entire intestine or of a portion of the intestine.

value: Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa
definition: An abnormality of the pigmentation of the mucosa of the mouth.

Coarse appearance of the components of the network of osseous tissue that makes up the cancellous structure of a bone, i.e., thickening of the (usually fine) white lines that are produced by trabeculae in radiograms.
Abnormal structure or form of trabecular bone.
The presence of a hernia of the vagina.
A type of hydrocele testis in which the processus vaginalis remains patent only around the testes, and, as fluid accumulates, it renders the testes impalpable.
Varicosity of veins in the vulval region.
The presence of an increased degree of wrinkling (irregular folds and indentations) of the skin as compared with age-related norms.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication of a portion of the muscle and submucosa of the esophagus without epithelial duplication.
A congenital absence or considerable underdevelopment of the trachea such that communication between the larynx proximally and the alveoli of the lungs distally is lacking.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a salivary gland.
An abnormality of Sharpey's fibers (bone fibers, or perforating fibers), which are a matrix of connective tissue consisting of bundles of strong collagenous fibres connecting periosteum to bone.
The presence of an extra auricle on one or both sides of the head.
A decreased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.

value: Abnormality of the curvature of the cornea

definition: An increase in the degree of curvature of the cornea compared to normal.
Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
Tibial torsion is inward twisting (medial rotation) (PATO:0002155) of the tibia.
Excess deposit and expansion of adipose tissue in an unusual pattern which cannot be lost through diet and exercise .
A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
The presence of Neurofibromas in the subcutis.
An abnormality of the Arachnoid mater.
An abnormality of the pia mater.
An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid.
A form of loss of vision caused by damage to the visual cortex rather than a defect in the eye.
An abnormality of the glia cell.

One of the three types of glia cells that, with the nerve cells, compose the central nervous system and are characterized by sheetlike processes that wrap around individual axons to form the myelin sheath of nerve fibers.
An abnormality of astrocytes.
An abnormality of the microglial cells. They are also known as brain-resident macrophages or hortega cells.

Acting on the spur of the moment in response to immediate stimuli; acting on a momentary basis without a plan or consideration of outcomes; difficulty establishing or following plans; a sense of urgency and self-harming behavior under emotional distress.
An abnormality of the thoracic vertebral column.
Any structural abnormality of the lumbar vertebral column.
Aggression towards oneself.

Any structural anomaly of the cementum, which is the mineralized connective tissue covering the dental root. The cementum allows anchoring of the fibers of the periodontal ligament. Cementum is secreted by cementoblasts, which may be, later on, embedded in the cementum. Cementum can be acellular (along the two third coronal portion of the root) and cellular (in the apical and interradicular part of the root).
A sectoral indentation of the crystalline lens, usually due to zonular weakness or absence.

Swelling of lymph nodes within the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavities that contains the heart and the great vessels, the esophagus, and trachea and other structures including lymph nodes.
An abnormality of coagulation associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.

A systemic disease which can present with cutaneous lesions with or without internal involvement. Tumors are caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).
An excessive number of histiocytes (tissue macrophages).
A rare congenital cystic lesion of the lungs in the mediastinum.
A horizontal cleft of the face, varying from slight widening of the mouth, to a cleft extending to the ear.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the parathyroid gland.
An anomaly of one or more epiphyses of one or more vertebrae.
An abnormality of the soft palate.
Abnormal eating habit with excessive or insufficient consumption of food or any other abnormal pattern of food consumption.

A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the vascular system.
An anomaly of the joint between the trochlear notch of ulna and the trochlea of humerus, which is part of the elbow joint.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several fingers.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several toes.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest.
Collapse of part of a lung associated with absence of inflation (air) of that part.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the esophagus.
Formation of abnormal lobules (small masses of tissue) in the liver.

A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%.
A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.
A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas.
A serious and potentially life-threatening condition that arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis).
Terminal broadening of the fingers (distal phalanges of the fingers).
Terminal broadening of the toes (distal phalanges of the toes).
Bleeding into the biliary tree.

An anomaly of the lymphatic system, a network of lymphatic vessels that carry a clear fluid called lymph unidirectionally towards either the right lymphatic duct or the thoracic duct, which in turn drain into the right and left subclavian veins respectively.

Lymphangiomas are rare congenital malformations consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures. Lymphangioma is usually asymptomatic due to its soft consistency but compression of adjacent structures can be seen due to the mass effect of a large tumor.
An abnormality of the tonsils.
A structural anomaly of the vessel that contains or conveys lymph fluid.
An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.

A malignant, trophoblastic and aggressive cancer, usually of the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and belongs to the far end of the spectrum of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a subset of germ cell tumors.
Excessively active peristalsis (wave of contraction of the tubular organs of the gastrointestinal tract) marked by excessive rapidity of the passage of food through the stomach and intestine.
Reduced or inadequate peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the digestive tract.
Excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue.
A widening or ballooning of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord usually at the lumbosacral level.
An increased susceptibility to pharyngitis as manifested by a history of recurrent pharyngitis.
An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.
A rare birth defect in women where the urethra and vagina both open into a common channel.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
An anomaly of the sacroiliac joint, which connects the base of the spine (sacrum) to the ilium (a hip bone).
Failure to develop and congenital absence of the breast.
Persistent difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep.
Lack of separation of the upper and lower lips.
A bony protrusion present on the midline of the hard palate.
The loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.
The absence of the normal curvature of the vertebral column.
Testicular inflammation.
An abnormality of the development of the toenails.
An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the middle ear.
A congenital underdevelopment (aplasia or hypoplasia) of the pancreas.
Aplasia of the pancreas.
Abnormal anatomical location of the stomach. This feature may be due to intestinal malrotation.
An abnormality of the region around the nails of the fingers or toes.
Flesh-colored papule in or around the nail bed. Ungual fibromas may be periungual (arising under the proximal nail fold) or subungual (originating under the nail plate).
Systemic inflammatory response to infection.

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
An outpouching of the gastric wall.
Pain or discomfort of the scalp elicited by palpation.
Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the colon.
Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
Testicular torsion is when the spermatic cord to a testicle twists, cutting off the blood supply. The most common symptom is acute testicular pain.
The presence of hypertension related to stenosis of the renal artery.
Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
An abnormal connection between the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, urethra, vagina, or other regions of the gastrointestinal tract.
Inflammatory or noninflammatory diseases affecting the glomeruli of the nephron.
The prolapse of the female urethra into the vagina.

A Rectocele results from a tear in the rectovaginal septum (which is normally a tough, fibrous, sheet-like divider between the rectum and vagina). Rectal tissue bulges through this tear and into the vagina as a hernia. There are two main causes of this tear: childbirth, and hysterectomy.
Inflammation of the lip.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nail.
Increase in the number or proportion of lymphocytes in the blood.
An abnormal increase in the total number of T cells detected in the blood.
Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin with a role in promoting the coagulation cascade.
Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.
The presence of a neoplasm of the small intestine.
The presence of a neoplasm of the large intestine.

value: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
definition: A tumor that originates in the pineal gland, has moderate cellularity and tends to form rosette patterns.

Symmetrical vermiform facial atrophy that affects mainly the forehead, the chin, the ear lobes and helices. Atrophodermia vermiculata is characterized by erythema and follicular plugs on the cheeks, developing into painless reticular impressions.
An increased susceptibility to cutaneous abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent cutaneous abscesses.
Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyebrow.
A developmental anomaly wtih a small tubular or saccular midline stomach.
Underdevelopment of the optic nerve and absence of the septum pellucidum.
An acute hypersensitivity reaction due to exposure to a previously encountered antigen.
A chronic, relapsing, pustular eruption that is localized to the palms and soles.

value: Neoplasm of the male external genitalia
definition: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the male external genitalia.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the scrotum.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the penis.
An abnormality of emotional behaviour.
An abnormality of fear/anxiety-related behavior, which may relate to either abnormally reduced fear/anxiety-related response or increased fear/anxiety-related response.
Underdevelopment of the areola, the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
Absence of the musculature.
Hypoplasia of the triceps muscle.
Decreased ossification of the vertebral bodies.
An abnormally flat sella turcica.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the celiac artery.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the superior mesenteric artery .
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery .
Increase in bone density of the vertebral body.
An abnormally short femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
Increased width of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
Underdevelopment of the iliac bones.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
The presence of telangiectases on the skin of palm of hand.
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located on the skin of sole of foot.
An abnormality of the palm, that is, of the front of the hand.

value: Abnormality of the plantar skin of foot
definition: An abnormality of the plantar part of foot, that is of the soles of the feet.
Increased density of hairs, i.e., and elevated number of hairs per unit area.
Increased length and width of one half of the tounge.
Skin crease extending from below the inner canthus laterally along the malar process of the maxilla and zygoma.
Cystic, urine-containing intrarenal cavities lined with transitional cell epithelium that communicate through a narrow channel with the collecting system.
Abnormally persistent clusters of embryonal cells, representing microscopic malformations (dysplasias) of the developing kidney.

Congenital mesoblastic nephroma is a type of kidney tumor that is usually found before birth by ultrasound or within the first 3 months of life. It contains fibroblastic cells (connective tissue cells), and may spread to the other kidney or to nearby tissue.
A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life.
Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels.

A scoliosis which is the results of a difference in leg length (which might be due to hemihypertrophy or hemihypotrophy of a leg) and the resulting tilting of the pelvis. If untreated this will lead to the development of scoliosis over time.
Persistence of the embryonic dorsal or sciatic vein system that normally should have involuted around the tenth to twelfth week of intrauterine life.
An abnormality in the placement of the ocular globe (eyeball).
An abnormality in the size of the ocular globe (eyeball).
An abnormality of the Common bile duct, a tube-like anatomic structure in the human gastrointestinal tract, formed by the union of the Common hepatic duct and the Cystic duct from the gall bladder.
A cleft of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
An abnormality of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
Increased prominence of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
Increased side-to-side width of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
The presence of multiple rectal hyperplastic/adenomatous polyps.
Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 4th finger
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 5th finger
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
definition: An elevation of bone density in the distal phalanx of the thumb.

value: Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
definition: An elevation of bone density in the proximal phalanx of the thumb.
An elevation in bone density in one or more distal phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more middle phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more proximal phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the second finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the third finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fourth finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fifth finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An increase in bone density within the clavicle.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the toes. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more foot bones. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the second toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fourth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fifth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the big toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
definition: An elevation in bone density in the proximal phalanx of the second toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
definition: An elevation in bone density in the proximal phalanx of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd toe
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
definition: An elevation in bone density in the middle phalanx of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 4th toe
Sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
definition: An elevation in bone density in the distal phalanx of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

value: Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 4th toe
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the hallux
Sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the hallux

definition: An elevation in bone density in one or more proximal phalanges of the toes. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more middle phalanges of the toes. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more distal phalanges of the toes. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An increase in size of the subarachnoid space associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).
Underdevelopment of the operculum.
Any structural abnormality of the medulla of the kidney.
Decreased width of the foramen obturatorium. The foramen obturatorium (also known as the obturator foramen) is a hole located between the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis.

Dense radiopaque bands of bone which are thicker than the adjacent diaphyseal cortex and may form at the metaphysis of growing bones. They appear on radiographs as bone that is more radiopaque that the adjacent diaphyseal cortex.
Increase in size of the hippocampus.
Increased sensitivity to stimulation, excluding the special senses, which may refer to various modes of cutaneous sensibility including touch and thermal sensation without pain, as well as to pain.
Different levels of maturation of different bones.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is an acceleration in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.
Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.

value: Abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure
definition: The presence of an abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure.

value: Abnormal size of the palpebral fissures
definition: An abnormal size of the palpebral fissures for example unusually long or short palpebral fissures.
The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of adipose tissue.
Overgrowth of the stratum corneum characterized by flesh-coloured or slightly pigmented smooth or warty papules on the upper surface of hands and feet.
Congenital defect with failure of the development of the cerebral white matter.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
An erosion or abrasion of the cornea's outermost layer of epithelial cells.
Low set, steeply sloping shoulders.
Choroid plexus papilloma is a histologically benign neoplasm located in the ventricular system of the choroid plexus.
A painful and harmful medical condition in which the erect penis doesn't return to its flaccid state, despite the absence of both physical and psychological stimulation, within four hours.
The presence of premature sister chromatid segregation.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the mandible.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye.
A diffuse, non-pitting edema and thickening of the skin usually on the anterior aspect of the lower legs spreading to the dorsum of the feet.
Grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea.
A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A plaque is a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.
Morphologically similar to a papule, but greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat.
A circumscribed, fluid-containing, epidermal elevation generally considered less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.

Nontender, round and firm, but slightly compressible, intradermal or subcutaneous cyst measuring 0.5-5 cm in diameter. Epidermal cysts are intradermal or subcutaneous tumors, grow slowly and occur on the face, neck, back and scrotum. They usually appear at or around puberty, and as a rule an affected individual has one solitary or a few cysts.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting incomplete loss of the epidermis, a lesion that is moist, circumscribed, and usually depressed.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting complete loss of the epidermis and often portions of the dermis and even subcutaneous fat.
Warts, benign growths on the skin or mucous membranes that cause cosmetic problems as well as pain and discomfort. Warts most often occur on the hands, feet, and genital areas.
A clonal disorder of keratinization with one or multiple atrophic patches surrounded by a clinically and histologically distinctive hyperkeratotic ridgelike border called the cornoid lamella.
The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
Inflammation of the cartilage of the external ear.
Shortening of a leg affecting only one side.
Disproportionately small hand.
Scar tissue in the macula.

An aberrant pupillary response characterized by (i) Constriction of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is applied to the normal eye, and (ii) Dilatation of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is rapidly transferred from the normal eye (after brief light exposure to the normal eye) to the affected eye.
Multiple abnormal growths that arise from the lining of the large intestine (colon or rectum) and protrude into the intestinal lumen.
Asymmetry between the two irides or asymmetry between different parts of one iris.
Repeated episodes of abortion (Expulsion of the product of fertilization before completing the term of gestation) without deliberate interference.
A type of vitreoretinal degeneration with manifestations that are concentrated at the periphery of the retina.
Intermittent episodes of paralysis of all four limbs.

value: Respiratory insufficiency due to defective ciliary clearance

definition: Chronic hepatitis characterized by parenchymal inflammation with formation of large multinucleated hepatocytes in response to a variety of insults to the liver.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth, in which the upper lip is tented in a way that the opened mouth has the appearance of a triangle.
Blisters arising in the mouth.
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring).
Absence of nail of little finger.
Metabolic alkalosis is defined as a disease state where the pH is elevated to greater than 7.45 secondary to some metabolic process.

value: Recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections
definition: Increased susceptibility to upper and lower respiratory tract infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of upper and lower respiratory tract infections.
Acute hepatic injury resulting from inflammation typically accompanied by increased serum alanine transaminase activity. Etiologies include viral hepatitis, drugs, toxins, and autoimmune disorders.
Chronic hepatitis associated with recurrent clinical exacerbations, extrahepatic manifestations, and progression to cirrhosis.
Hepatitis that lasts for more than six months.

value: Chronic hepatitis due to cryptosporidium infection
definition: Chronic hepatitis associated with infection by cryptosporidia, as demonstrated (for example) by immunohistochemistry of liver tissue.
Any complex of structural, architectural, contractile or electrophysiological changes affecting the atria with the potential to produce clinically relevant manifestations.
Thickening of the heart walls in both ventricles.

A condition in which epileptiform abnormalities are believed to contribute to the progressive disturbance in cerebral function. Epileptic encephalaopathy is characterized by (1) electrographic EEG paroxysmal activity that is often aggressive, (2) seizures that are usually multiform and intractable, (3) cognitive, behavioral and neurological deficits that may be relentless, and (4) sometimes early death.

An increase of medial mucoid extracellular matrix creating translamellar and/or intralamellar expansions including extracellular pools as noted on an H&E stain and/or a stain to highlight extracellular matrix material (Movat's pentachrome, Alcian blue, etc.).
A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the basal ganglia.

value: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy

definition: An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.

value: Increased serum bile acid concentration during pregnancy

definition: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells in cutaneous tissue.

value: Agenesis of permanent mandibular lateral incisor
Agenesis of primary mandibular lateral incisor

definition: Increased vertical distance from the vermillion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
Vertical crease fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin with the face at rest.
Folds or ridges within the concha that are distinct from the crus helix.

value: Focal absence of the external ear
definition: Absence of a localized portion of the ear that cannot be described by a more precise term (e.g., absent ear lobe).
Median longitudinal ear length greater than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
Median longitudinal ear length less than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
Frequent menses; menstrual cycles lasting less than 21 days.
Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals.
An abnormality of the vomer.

Alveolar cleft is a tornado-shaped bone defect in the maxillary arch. Alveolar cleft occurs in response to divergence from normal development during frontonasal prominence growth, contact, and fusion. The most common alveolar portion of the cleft is located between the lateral incisor and the canine.
Abnormality of the first branch of the internal carotid artery.

value: Abnormality of the peripheral nervous system
definition: Any abnormality of the part of the nervous system that consists of the nerves and ganglia outside of the brain and spinal cord.

value: Abnormality of the somatic nervous system
definition: Any abnormality of the part of the peripheral nervous system associated with sensation and skeletal muscle voluntary control of body movements.
Any abnormality of the somatic nerve plexus.
Any abnormality of the masticatory muscle.
Any abnormality of the mouth floor.

Any abnormality of the submandibular region, the region between the mandible and the hyoid bone contains the submandibular and sublingual glands, suprahyoid muscles, submandibular ganglion, and lingual artery.
An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the autonomic nervous system.

value: Abnormality of ganglion of peripheral nervous system
definition: An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the peripheral autonomic nervous system.
An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the autonomic nervous system of the cranium.
Inflammation or infection of the external auditory canal (EAC), the auricle, or both.
Increased susceptibility to ear infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of ear infections.
Pain that is localized to the region of the upper abdomen immediately below the ribs.
Body odor characterized by an offensive body odor and the smell of rotting fish due to the excessive excretion of trimethylamine (TMA) in the urine, sweat, and breath of affected individuals.
Pungent body odor.
A fish odor in the vaginal area, that is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV), and is due to trimethylamine (TMA).

value: Abnormal distribution of cell junction proteins in buccal mucosal cells
definition: An anomalous amount or location of cell junction proteins such as plakoglobin or Cx43.
Any abnormality of the periodontium.
A decrease in the amount of alveolar bone around the root of a tooth.
Recurrent episodes of oral herpes, typically characterized by blisters or ulcers on the gums, lips and/or tongue caused by herpes virus.
A gap in the lip or lips.

value: Submucous cleft of soft and hard palate
definition: Soft and hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the soft and hard palate that are covered by the lining (ie mucous membrane) of the roof of the mouth.
One sided alveolar cleft of the maxilla.
Nonmidline alveolar cleft of the maxilla.

Any abnormality in the activation of T cells, i.e. the change in morphology and behavior of a mature or immature T cell resulting from exposure to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
Any structural anomaly of the bile-secreting organ that is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage.
Any structural anomaly of the hollow epithelial tube found on the dorsal side of the vertebrate embryo that develops into the central nervous system (i.e. brain and spinal cord).

value: Decreased level of 1,5 anhydroglucitol in serum
definition: A decrease in the level of 1,5 anhydroglucitol in the serum. 1,5-Anhydrosorbitol is a validated marker of short-term glycemic control. This substance is derived mainly from food, is well absorbed in the intestine, and is distributed to all organs and tissues.

value: Increased level of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric acid in urine
definition: An increase in the level of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric acid in the urine.

value: Increased level of allantoin in serum
definition: An increase in the level of allantoin in the serum.

value: Increased level of GABA in serum
definition: An increase in the level of GABA in the serum.

value: Increased level of D-threitol in plasma

value: Increased level of D-threitol in CSF

value: Increased level of D-threitol in urine

definition: A decrease in the level of D-mannose in the urine.

value: Increased level of galactitol in plasma
definition: An increase in the level of galactitol in the plasma.

value: Increased level of galactitol in urine

definition: An increase in the level of galactitol in the red blood cells.

value: Increased level of L-glutamic acid in blood
definition: An increase in the level of L-glutamic acid in the blood.

value: Increased level of propylene glycol in blood
definition: An increase in the level of propylene glycol in the blood.

value: Increased level of ribitol in urine
definition: An increase in the level of ribitol in the urine. Ribotol is a crystalline pentose alcohol (C5H12O5) and is a metabolic end product formed by the reduction of ribose.

value: Increased level of ribitol in CSF
definition: An increase in the level of ribitol in the cerebral spinal fluid.

value: Increased level of ribose in urine
definition: An increase in the level of ribose in the urine.

value: Increased level of xylitol in urine
definition: An increase in the level of xylitol in the urine.

value: Increased level of xylitol in CSF
definition: An increase in the level of xylitol in the cerebrospinal fluid.

value: Increased level of L-pyroglutamic acid in urine
definition: An increase in the level of L-pyroglutamic acid in the urine.
Urticaria characterized by spontaneously recurring hives for 6 weeks or longer.
Urticaria caused by physical agents, such as heat, cold, light, friction.
Urticaria may be caused by cold temperatures.
A form of physical urticaria, in which contact with water, regardless of its temperature and source, evokes pruritic follicular wheals on the skin.
Urticaria in response to exposure to ultraviolet-A (UVA), ultraviolet-B (UVB), visible and rarely infrared light.
Urticaria in response to dermal vibration, with coincident degranulation of mast cells and increased histamine levels in serum.
Anaphylaxis after physical activity.
An abnormality in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.
A decrease in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.
An increase in biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.

value: Eosinophilic infiltration in the stomach mucosa
definition: Infiltration of eosinophils in the stomach mucosa, that is diagnosed by an upper endoscopy and microscopy that shows more than 20 eosinophils per high-power field in association with peripheral eosinophilia and the absence of secondary cause of eosinophilia.
A rare form of anaphylaxis for which triggers cannot be identified despite a detailed history and careful diagnostic assessment.
A form of anaphylaxis that is triggered by intake of drugs or medications.
Infiltration of numerous eosinophils (usually greater than 15 per high power field) into the squamous epithelium of the esophagus, and layering of eosinophils on the surface layer of the esophagus.

value: Eosinophilic microabscess formation in the esophagus
definition: The formation of small localized collection of eosinophiles (an eosinophilic microabscess) in the esophagus. Usually clusters of greater than or equal to 4 eosinophils are seen, that appear as exudates or white spots or white plaques.

value: Increased level of methylsuccinic acid in urine
definition: An increase in the level of methylsuccinic acid in the urine.

value: Increased level of myristic acid in serum
definition: An increase in the level of myristic acid in the serum.

value: Increased level of N-acetylneuraminic acid in urine
definition: An increase in the level of N-acetylneuraminic acid in the urine.

value: Increased level of N-acetylneuraminic acid in fibroblasts
definition: An increase in the level of N-acetylneuraminic acid in cultured fibroblasts.
An increase in the level of O-phosphoethanolamine in the urine.

A defect in the of the process of interstrand cross-link repair: removal of a DNA interstrand crosslink (a covalent attachment of DNA bases on opposite strands of the DNA) and restoration of the DNA. DNA interstrand crosslinks occur when both strands of duplex DNA are covalently tethered together (e.g. by an exogenous or endogenous agent), thus preventing the strand unwinding necessary for essential DNA functions such as transcription and replication.

value: Abnormal morphology of the chest musculature
definition: Any abnormality of the chest muscles.
Any abnormality of the back muscles.

value: Abnormal morphology of the shoulder musculature
definition: Any abnormality of the shoulder muscles.
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of hippocampus tissue that was once present.
Increased concentration of cotinine in urine.
The presence of a xenobiotic in blood.

An increased concentration of tropnin I in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

An increased concentration of tropnin T in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
An increase in the level of ketone bodies (acetoacetic acid, beta-hydroxybutyric acid, and acetone) in the blood.
An anomaly in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase.

value: Abnormal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in blood
definition: An anomaly in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the blood.

value: Increased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in blood
definition: An increase in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the blood.

value: Decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in blood
definition: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the blood.

value: Abnormal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in dried blood spot
definition: An anomaly in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in a dried blood spot.

value: Increased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in dried blood spot
definition: An increase in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in a dried blood spot.

value: Decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in dried blood spot
definition: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in a dried blood spot.

value: Abnormal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in leukocytes

value: Abnormal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in red blood cells
definition: An anomaly in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in red blood cells.

value: Abnormal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in tissue
definition: An anomaly in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in tissue.

value: Increased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in tissue
definition: An increase in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in tissue.

definition: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in tissue.

value: Decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in red blood cells
definition: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in red blood cells.

value: Increased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in red blood cells
definition: An increase in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in red blood cells.

value: Decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in leukocytes
definition: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in leukocytes.

value: Increased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in leukocytes
definition: An increase in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in leukocytes.
An abnormality in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level, an enzyme that catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Abnormal uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma
definition: An abnormality in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Increased uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma
definition: An increase in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Decreased uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma
definition: A decrease in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Abnormal uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells
definition: An abnormality in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Increased uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells
definition: An increase in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

value: Decreased uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells
definition: A decrease in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in red blood cells. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.
Increased concentration of urate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Detection of barbiturate metabolites such as phenobarbital in meconium.
Detection of barbiturate metabolites such as phenobarbital in the hair.
Detection of barbiturate metabolites such as phenobarbital in the stool.
Detection of barbiturate metabolites such as phenobarbital in the gastric fluid.
An increase in the length of time required for food to pass through the intestines.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of nicotinurate in the blood.
An increased amount of nicotinurate in the blood.
Detection of methadone or its metabolite 2-ethylidene-1,5-dimethyl-3,3- diphenylpyrrolidine (EDDP) in plasma or serum.
Detection of cotinine, an alkaloid found in tobacco and the predominant metabolite of nicotine, in plasma or serum.
A reduced concentration of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9 in the cerebrospinal fluid.
An abnormality in any umbilical cord measurement performed after birth, such as the blood gas level.

value: Abnormal blood gas level in cord blood

definition: An abnormally high level of blood oxygen in the cord blood.
An abnormally low level of blood oxygen in the cord blood.
Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level in the cord blood.
Abnormally decreased blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level in the cord blood.
An abnormal concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate in the blood.
A decreased concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate in the blood.

value: Hypoplasia of maxilla relative to mandible
definition: Abnormally small dimension of the maxilla (upper jaw) relative to the mandible (lower jaw).

value: Hypoplasia of mandible relative to maxilla
definition: Abnormally small dimension of the mandible (lower jaw) relative to the maxilla (upper jaw).

value: Increased anti-dairy protein IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against dairy proteins, including casein, alpha-lactalbumin, beta-lactoglobulin or bovine serum albumin contained in cow, sheep or goat milk and milk products.

value: Increased anti-animal protein IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against animal proteins, such as albumins that are present in animal hair, dander, shed skin, saliva and urine.
Increased level of IgE antibody against seafood, including fish, shrimp, lobster, crab, squid and abalone.

value: Increased anti-dust mite IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against dust mites, such as house dust mites.
Increased level of IgE antibody against bacteria.
Increased level of IgE antibody against a drug or class of drugs, such as antibiotics.
Increased level of IgE antibody against feathers, which could be indicative of an allergy against feathers themselves, or mite allergens present in feathers.

value: Increased anti-food allergen IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against proteins found in foods, such as milk, egg, soy, wheat, peanut, treenut, fish, and shellfish.

value: Increased anti-plant based food allergen IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against a plant based food allergen, including vegetables and fruits.
Increased level of IgE antibody against gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

value: Increased anti-nut food product IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against nut food products such as peanuts or tree nuts, such as hazelnuts, walnuts, cashews, and almonds.
Increased level of IgE antibody against eggs, including egg whites, egg yolks, and egg proteins such as ovoalbumin and ovomucoid.
Increased level of IgE antibody against fungus, such as molds like zygomycota, ascomycota and deuteromycota.

value: Increased anti-meat allergen IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against meat, such as mammalian meat, including beef or pork, or poultry, like duck or chicken.

Increased level of IgE antibody against parasites, such as helminths (parasitic worms, such as Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura, Ancylostoma duodenalis, Necator americanus, Strongyloides stercoralis) or parasites such as Toxoplasma gondii.
Increased level of IgE antibody against antigens from insects such as moths, mosquitos, or cockroaches.
Increased level of IgE antibody against venom from insects such as bees, wasps, hornets, yellowjackets.

value: Increased anti-plant product IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against antigens from plants and products derived from plants, such as wood or pollen.
Detection of norcotinine, a metabolite of nicotine, in urine.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgA immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgE immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgG immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgM immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgD immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin D (IgD) in blood.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin D in blood.

value: Increased anti-animal dander IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against animal dander, tiny scales shed from animal skin or hair, such as from pet dogs or cats.

value: Increased anti-house dust mite IgE antibody level
definition: Increased level of IgE antibody against house dust mites, a common allergen.
Increased level of IgE antibody against galactose-alpha-1, 3 galactose (alpha-gal), a carbohydrate found in mammalian meat.

An abnormality in the cleavage of L-selectin during the process of guiding neutrophils to the site of infection. Proteolytic cleavage of L-selectin results in rapid shedding from the cell surface, which has a role in neutrophil rolling and accumulation at the site of infection.
Neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 1,500,000,000/L lasting for more than 3 months.
Chornic neutropenia arising from an impaired proliferation and maturation of myeloid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.

value: Cyclic neutropenia in myeloid maturation arrest in bone marrow
definition: Cyclic neutropenia arising from an impaired proliferation and maturation of myeloid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.
A transient reduction in the number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood. Transient neutropenia is most commonly associated with viral infections, but other causes include drugs and autoimmunity.
Transient neutropenia caused by an infection, such as with a virus, bacteria or protozoan.
An increased number of neutrophils circulating in the blood during an infection, such as with a bacteria, virus or fungus.
An increased number of neutrophils circulating in the blood in the absence of an infection. Factors contributing to neutrophilia could include inflammation or congenital disorders.
Fusion of the liver with the lung.
The presence of an asymmetrical gluteal crease, the horizontal crease formed by the inferior aspect of the buttocks and the posterior upper leg.
A widely spaced gap between the fourth toe and the fifth (pinky) toe.
A functional abnormality affecting the lower cranial nerves, which include the paired 9th (glossopharyngeal), 10th (vagal), 11th (accessory) and 12th (hypoglossal) cranial nerves.
An anomaly of metabolism or structure of the brain identified by imaging.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the airway, typically below the vocal chords, that can cause severe obstruction of the airway.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the upper part of the larynx (voice box) including the epiglottis; the area above the vocal cords.
A hemangioma arising from within visceral structures, the internal organs of the body.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the intestines, which includes the bowel.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the spleen.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the upper lip.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the esophagus.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the glottic or supraglottic regions.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the vulva.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the retropharyngeal space, the portion of the peripharyngeal space that is located posterior to the pharynx.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the paraspinal muscular region, the muscles next to the spine.
A spinal cord hemangioma located in the lumbosacral spine region.

An abnormality of the sternum that presents at birth as a ventral sternal non-union defect, due to an abnormality of the fusion of the layers of the skin. It presents as a scar-like line that extends upward from the umbilicus (belly button).
A sternal pit is a small indentation or dimple in the skin overlying the sternum of the chest. In some cases, the skin defect can be linear, extending several inches over the sternum.
A fluid-filled sacs that develop on or near the pituitary gland.
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of the pituitary gland.
Onset of disease manifestations before adulthood, defined here as before the age of 15 years, but excluding neonatal or congenital onset.

A heterogeneous group of symptoms that are localized in the epigastric region. Typical dyspeptic symptoms include postprandial fullness, early satiation, epigastric pain and epigastric burning, but other upper gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, belching or abdominal bloating often occur.
A deviation from the normal concentration of amylase in the blood, an enzyme which helps digest glycogen and starch. It is produced mainly in the pancreas and salivary glands.
Detection of acetaminophen in the blood.
Detection of norpropoxyphene in the blood, a major metabolite of the opioid analgesic drug dextropropoxyphene.
Detection of methadone or its metabolite 2-ethylidene-1,5-dimethyl-3,3- diphenylpyrrolidine (EDDP) in meconium.
Detection of molindone in the blood, an antipyschotic used for treatment of schizophrenia.
A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the intrathoracic or chest region.
Increased level of amylase in the blood, an enzyme which helps digest glycogen and starch. It is produced mainly in the pancreas and salivary glands.
Decreased level of amylase in the blood, an enzyme which helps digest glycogen and starch. It is produced mainly in the pancreas and salivary glands.
Detection of norpropoxyphene in urine.
Opposing or not responding to instructions or external stimuli.

An abnormal level of isohemagglutinin in the blood. An isohemagglutinin refers to the naturally occurring antibodies in the ABO blood group system (i.e., anti-A in a group B person, anti-B in a group A person, and anti-A, anti-B, and anti-A,B in a group O person).

Absent or undetectable level of isohemagglutinin. An isohemagglutinin refers to the naturally occurring antibodies in the ABO blood group system (i.e., anti-A in a group B person, anti-B in a group A person, and anti-A, anti-B, and anti-A,B in a group O person).

value: Decreased specific antibody response to protein vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against proteins in vaccines, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to tetanus vaccine
definition: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a tetanus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to hepatitis B vaccine
definition: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a hepatisis B antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Partial absence of specific antibody response to tetanus vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a tetanus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Partial absence of specific antibody response to hepatitis B vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a hepatitis B antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against polysaccharides in vaccines, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to unconjugated pneumococcus vaccine
definition: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a pneumococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Partial absence of specific antibody response to unconjugated pneumococcus vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a pneumococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Decreased specific antibody response to protein-conjugated polysaccharide vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against protein-conjugated polysaccharides in vaccines, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine

value: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to meningococcus vaccine
definition: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a meningococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Partial absence of specific antibody response to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

value: Partial absence of specific antibody response to meningococcus vaccine
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a meningococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.
Detection of methadone and its metabolites in the stool.

value: Decreased specific antibody response to infection
definition: A reduced ability to synthesize antibodies against antigens from an infectious agent or pathogen (such as bacteria, viruses, parasites, etc.), as measured by antibody titer determination following infection.
A increased concentration of alpha-aminoadipic acid in the urine.

value: Abnormality of neutrophil morphology in CSF
definition: An abnormal form or size of neutrophils in the cerebrospinal fluid.

value: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
definition: Hyposegmented (hypolobulated) or bilobed neutrophil nuclei in the cerebrospinal fluid.

value: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
definition: An excessive division of the lobes of the nucleus of a neutrophil in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Abnormal concentration of 1-methylhistidine in the urine.
Decreased concentration of 1-methylhistidine in the urine.
Increased concentration of 1-methylhistidine in the urine.
Abnormal amount of 3-methylhistidine in the urine.
Increased concentration of 3-methylhistidine in the urine.

Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against animal proteins.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against animal dander.

An abnormal increase in the concentration of heparan sulfate in the blood.
An abnormal decrease in the concentration of heparan sulfate in the blood.

An abnormal decrease in the concentration of high-mannose N-glycans on glycoproteins.
An abnormal in the concentration of core 1 O-glycans on glycoproteins.
An abnormal increase in the concentration of core 1 O-glycans on glycoproteins.
An abnormal decrease in the concentration of core 1 O-glycans on glycoproteins.

Hypoglycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan with O-mannosyl glycans. Alpha-dystroglycan is a functional target of O-mannosyl glycosylation and functional glycosylation of alpha-DG is essential in its interaction with the extracellular matrix.
An abnormal increase in the concentration of monosialylated core 1 O-glycans on glycoproteins.
An abnormal decrease in the concentration of monosialylated core 1 O-glycans on glycoproteins.

value: Decreased proportion of naive CD4 T cells

value: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
definition: An abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.

value: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
definition: An abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. A CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype is CD45RO and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.

value: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
definition: An abnormal proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.

Abnormal proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
